    Collection of Medical Texts from Ancient and Modern Times, Volume 430

    Pediatric Diagnosis and Examination Section

    Huangdi's Spiritual Pivot Classic

    On Diagnosing Diseases with the Pulse

    If an infant's hair stands upright, it is certain to die.
    Note: This discusses the essence of human blood and qi, which originates from prenatal formation and circulates universally. An infant is a newborn. Hair is a surplus of blood, produced from the lesser yin essence. Hair that droops responds to blood and qi rising from below and descending from above. If hair stands upright, it means only rising and no descending occurs. The interplay of rising and falling ceases, hence death is inevitable.
    If the blue vein appears between the ears, it signifies pulling pain. (In the "Jia Yi Classic," this is described as abdominal pain.)
    Note: The kidneys govern the bones and open to the ears, thus the appearance of the blue vein between the ears indicates pain related to the tendons and bones. This is connected to the previous discussion regarding the blood and qi originating from the kidneys.
    Stools that are red indicate a condition. (In the "Jia Yi Classic," this is referred to as blue stools.)[1p]
    If the pulse is weak and the hands and feet are cold, it is difficult to resolve. If the pulse is weak but the hands and feet are warm, it is easy to resolve.

    Note: "Bian" means to differentiate. The term "red and differentiated stool" refers to a separation between yellow and red. This is because the middle jiao processes the turbid residues and transforms the essence into blood, circulating in the meridians, termed as nutrient qi. Food and drink normally reside together in the stomach, forming residue that descends into the large intestine, where it mixes with transformed fluid and seeps into the bladder. If the stool is red and differentiated, it implies that the blood in the middle jiao is being expelled along with the residue. When there is diarrhea, the large intestine is deficient and cannot properly transform. In this case, the gastrointestinal system fails to nourish the pulse with its essence, hence the weak pulse. However, when the hands and feet are warm, it indicates that the lower jiao has vitality, making it easier to resolve. This indicates that the essence of food and drink in the middle jiao relies on the vitality of the lower jiao for transformation.[2p]
    "Xiang Er Jing" (The Examination of Children) by Yan Zhu of the Jin Dynasty

    Longevity and Mortality

    When a child is born, if their cries are long and continuous, it indicates a long life. If the cries cease and then suddenly become urgent, it suggests a short life. If the cries are scattered, it indicates that they will not reach adulthood. If the cries are deep, it also suggests they will not reach adulthood. If the umbilical cord has no blood, it is favorable. A small umbilical cord indicates a short life. If the body is soft and weak as if it has no bones, it suggests a short life. A bright and robust appearance indicates longevity. If the eyes open by themselves, it suggests they will not reach adulthood. If the eyes do not align correctly and move excessively, it is unfavorable. Sweating blood indicates many troubles and a short life. If there is no sweat, it suggests they will not reach adulthood. If urine is thick like fatty grease, it suggests they will not reach adulthood. If there are four fractures in the head, it indicates they will not reach adulthood. If the child constantly shakes their hands and feet, it indicates they will not reach adulthood. Early sitting, early walking, early teeth, and early speech are all signs of poor fate, not of a good person. If the hair on the head does not cover the scalp evenly, the child is unlikely to reach adulthood. Sparse hair indicates they will not be able to listen to others. If there is a swirl of hair on the forehead, it will bring early misfortune to the parents. If the occipital bone does not form properly, they may speak but will die. If the coccyx does not form properly, they may sit but will die. If the bones of the palm do not form properly, they may crawl but will die. If the heel bone does not form properly, they may walk but will die. If the kneecap does not form properly, they may stand but will die. If the body does not gather properly, they will die. If they have a fish-shaped mouth, they will die. If there is no living flesh between the thighs, they will die. If the jaw is broken, they will die. If the genitalia do not appear, they will die. If the scrotum is white underneath, they will die; if it is red, they will die. If the sutures of the skull are open and dark, it indicates longevity.[3p]
    Pulse Diagnosis
    (Jin Dynasty - Wang Shuhe)

    A Song on the Life and Death of Infants

    After nursing, if an infant vomits, and the pulse is chaotic with no worries,
    (Note: Changes in digestion and unregulated breathing, along with vomiting and a chaotic pulse, are not considered a disease.)
    When the pulse is tight and quick, it is affected by internal wind,
    When the pulse is slow, it indicates undigested milk.
    (Note: A tight and quick pulse in infants indicates wind and cold obstruction, leading to spleen disorders and undigested milk.)
    A tight, rapid, thin pulse may indicate some bitterness and is accompanied by vacuity and stagnant evil energy that can cause fright.
    (Note: A rapid and thin pulse is the normal state for infants; if it is also tight, there may be some external disturbance. A pulse that is vacuous and moist indicates the presence of evil energy causing fright.)
    In cases of dysentery with urgent pain in the intestines, a floating, strong pulse indicates the path back to the source.
    (Note: A floating and strong pulse is inappropriate for dysentery.)[4p]

    Song of the Fifteen External Signs

    Red veins above the eyes, descending into the pupils.
    Note: The Chi family says: the red veins relate to the heart, and the pupils to the kidneys; this indicates that the heart fire overpowers the kidney water. When water is depleted, it cannot nourish wood, leading to the kidneys and liver being exhausted. The "Entry" states: water and fire are obstructed and exhausted.

    Swelling at the temples, forming pits as well.
    Note: When heat prevails, there is swelling; when heat is extreme, there are depressions. All are signs of heat. The "Entry" states: the heart is exhausted.

    Nose dry and blackened.
    Note: Fire overcomes metal. The "Entry" states: the lungs are exhausted.

    Abdomen large with blue veins.
    Note: Wood overcomes earth. The "Entry" states: the spleen is exhausted and lacks nourishment.

    Eyes continuously staring, unable to blink.
    Note: The classics say: to return yet not blink is this. The "Entry" states: if the eyes gaze straight, then all five organs are exhausted.

    Fingernails are dark and blue, suddenly making crow sounds.
    Note: The lungs and liver are exhausted. The "Entry" states: dark blue fingernails indicate liver exhaustion; crow sounds mean there is energy going out but none coming in, indicating that the pulse is exhausted.

    The tongue extends out, biting the teeth.[5p]
    【Note: When the heart's vitality is extinguished. "Entering the Path" states: When the tongue relaxes, heart energy is lost; when the kidneys are bitten, the energy is lost.】 The fish gasps for breath, but does not make a sound.
    【Note: The open mouth of the fish that does not close is called the spleen's energy exhausted. Gasping for breath and crying silently is called the lung's energy exhausted.】 When the roundworm emerges, it is surely a sign of impending death.
    【Note: The roundworm lives in the stomach, nourished by grain. When the stomach is expended and no grain enters, the worm emerges.】 Quick medical intervention can save one in ten.
    【Note: Summarizing the previous fifteen conditions. Among children with this condition, only one in ten can be treated.】
    A Thousand Gold Prescriptions by Sun Simiao, Tang Dynasty

    General Discussion on Children

    For children above three years old and under one, observe their temperament to understand their potential for lifespan. Children who are perceptive and quick to understand often die young. Those who resemble the likes of Xiang Qiao and Yan Hui are examples. If a child's bones are well-formed and they exhibit grace and ease, requiring little effort for refinement, they tend to live long. Those who are quick-witted and agile in understanding others are also prone to early death, similar to figures like Yang Xiu and Kong Rong. From this perspective, one can glean insights about longevity. It is akin to plum blossoms blooming early, unaware of the winter's harshness; sweet chrysanthemums bloom late, ultimately achieving longevity. Therefore, delayed development suggests a sign of longevity.[6p]
    Pediatric Pulse Diagnosis

    By Qian Yi of the Song Dynasty

    Pulse Methods

    A tight and rapid pulse indicates disharmony of qi; a deep and slow pulse indicates food stagnation; a hurried and knotty pulse indicates a state of fright; a floating pulse indicates wind, while a deep and fine pulse indicates cold; a chaotic pulse cannot be treated.

    Note: The pulse reflects the body's constitution and is a precursor to pathological changes; it serves as a guideline for medication, thus it is essential to understand it clearly. The "Complete Guide to Pediatric Care" states that for children under one year old, one should check the three pulse positions at the tiger's mouth (the index finger) to assess illness. If the pulse from the Yin (the first position) reaches only to the Mao (the second position), it is easy to treat; if it connects to the Mao, it is difficult to treat; and if the Yin encroaches on the Mao or the Mao extends beyond the Chen (the third position), the chances of recovery are slim. If the pulse shows five colors, such as blue due to fright or purple due to diarrhea, one should categorize these accordingly. After one year of age, one can use a single finger to assess its three parts: the rapid, floating, and sinking pulses. By four to five years old, a pulse rate of seven or eight and fine is normal; nine signifies harm, and ten indicates exhaustion.[7p]
    The sixth and fifth positions are associated with emptiness and cold; a tight pulse indicates wind stroke, while a rapid pulse signifies external obstruction. If the pulse changes to a steaming quality, it must be disordered. If there is heat between the bones, the pulse will be deep and rapid. A floating pulse that is not harmonious indicates an insidious condition; a large and rapid floating pulse suggests wind-heat; a hidden knot indicates the accumulation of matter; a fine and subtle pulse points to consumption or abdominal pain; a floating and strong pulse suggests the presence of worms; a floating and slow pulse indicates stomach cold. This is the essential discussion of pulse diagnosis. However, for children, since their vital energy is not yet solidified, fright causes their energy to scatter, leading to a disordered pulse. Furthermore, one should also refer to the three positions and five pulses. The three positions involve examining the facial complexion, the pulse at the tiger's mouth, and the inch pulse. The five pulses include pressing on the forehead and diagnosing at Tai Chong, along with the three prior positions, collectively referred to as the five pulses. Although the treatment methods differentiate between deficiency and excess, actual conditions of excess are accompanied by strong disease energy and weak physical vitality, whereas deficiencies indicate both weak physical vitality and disease energy. The text states: "If the true qi is depleted, it leads to deficiency; if the evil qi prevails, it results in excess." It also states: "For deficiencies, replenish the root; for excesses, drain the branch." Master Dong Yuan states: "If the physical condition is full, it should be drained; if the physical condition is empty, it should be supplemented."[8p]
    Facial Diagnosis

    The left cheek corresponds to the liver, the right cheek to the lungs, the forehead to the heart, the nose to the spleen, and the chin to the kidneys. If the color is red, it indicates heat, and treatment should follow the symptoms.

    (Note: The left cheek corresponds to the liver; a blue color indicates proper function, while white indicates improper function. If the color is red, it denotes liver channel wind-heat, with symptoms of heat and discomfort. A dark blue-black color indicates convulsions and abdominal pain, while pale red indicates tidal fever and phlegm cough. The right cheek corresponds to the lungs; a white color indicates proper function, while red indicates improper function. If the redness is severe, it indicates cough, difficulty breathing, and chaos. Drinking water that reaches the kidneys can result in red and urgent urination or obstruction. The forehead corresponds to the heart; a red color indicates proper function, while black indicates improper function. A blue-black color indicates convulsions, abdominal pain, and crying; a light yellow indicates night sweats, dry hair, and bone heat. The nose corresponds to the spleen; a yellow color indicates proper function, while blue indicates improper function. A red color indicates spleen channel deficiency heat, with reduced appetite; deep yellow indicates constipation and a dry nose with nosebleeds. The chin corresponds to the kidneys; a black color indicates proper function, while yellow indicates improper function. A red color indicates heat in the kidneys and bladder, leading to obstruction of urination.)[9p]

    Eye Diagnosis

    If the inner eye is red, it indicates excess heat in the heart; use Daohong San. If it is light red, it indicates a deficiency of heat in the heart; use Shengxi San. If it is blue, it indicates excess heat in the liver; use Xieqing Wan. If it is light blue, it indicates a deficiency of heat in the liver; use Dihuang Wan. If it is yellow, it indicates excess heat in the spleen; use Xiehuang San. If it is slightly yellow, it indicates a deficiency of heat in the spleen; use Yihuang San. If the eye lacks brightness, it indicates kidney deficiency; use Dihuang Wan.

    Note: The eye is the essence of the five organs, each associated with a specific color. The white part of the eye belongs to the lungs, the black part belongs to the liver, the upper and lower eyelids belong to the spleen, the red vessels belong to the heart, and the pupil belongs to the kidneys. These colors reflect the primary conditions of the five organs. However, if the white part of the eye is red, it indicates the heart invading the lungs; if it is blue, it indicates the liver overacting; if it is black, it indicates the kidneys overpowering the lungs; if it is yellow, it indicates the spleen overpowering the lungs. The same goes for the other observations.

    Death Diagnosis

    There is irregular diarrhea, and the spirit seems fine. There is insatiable thirst, relieving it only to feel thirsty again. There is nasal discharge without sneezing. In severe illness, the mouth is dry and the patient cannot sleep. Signs include bluish-black spots on the lips, cheeks deeply red as if painted with rouge, flaring nostrils, and irregular, labored breathing. The face displays five colors, lacking clarity and luster.[10p]
    Book of Living People: Discussions on Pediatric Treatment
    By Zhu Hong, Song Dynasty

    Although the treatment methods for children and adults are generally the same, the dosages for children should be smaller, as their body heat is often lower. For ordinary colds with fever, runny nose, phlegm, cough, and thirst, use Xingsing San. If there is difficulty swallowing, with phlegm and a productive cough, use Shuzhangzi Decoction. If the head and body are warm, with yellowish stools and abdominal heat, use Sijun San, Lianqiao Drink, or Sanhuang Pills. If the head and body are warm, with white and foul-smelling stools, this indicates food stagnation in the stomach; use Shuangwan Pills. If the child has no other diseases but overindulges in food, leading to abdominal distention, fever, and headache, Shuangwan Pills can treat this. When a child has a warm body, painful head, restless spirit, red urine, and constipation, this is a severe heat condition; use Xinxin San or Tiaowei Chengqi Decoction. For headaches with fever and a fear of cold, this indicates a cold injury; use Shengma Decoction. If there's no sweating, use Mahuang Huangqing Decoction; if sweating occurs, use Shengma Huangqin Decoction—both are essential medicines.

    Children should not take excessive cooling medicines, as cold stomachs can provoke worms, leading to symptoms resembling fright. Doctors often misinterpret these conditions and mistakenly administer fright medicines, like Musk, which may lead to vomiting and chronic fright due to a weakened stomach. Children must exhibit clear signs of heat before any dispersing treatments are considered, and great caution should be taken with purgative pills. Instead, use ingredients like Dahuang and Chuanxiong to make decoctions that can help expel the accumulated heat. In essence, the pills with Ba Dou just serve to treat food stagnation.[11p]

    Pediatric Pulse Diagnosis

    For a child's pulse, press on the three sections with the thumb. A count of six to seven beats per breath is considered balanced and harmonious; eight to nine indicates fever, while five suggests internal cold. A tense pulse suggests wind-induced convulsions, a deep and slow pulse indicates food stagnation, a rapid pulse signifies fright, and a tense and rapid pulse means discord in Qi. A deep and fine pulse is indicative of cold, while a floating pulse points to wind. An uneven pulse in size suggests adverse signs and malefic spirits, while a floating and large pulse indicates wind or heat hidden causing accumulations, and a fine single pulse suggests malnutrition. If there is abdominal pain accompanied by a lot of wheezing and vomiting with a strong pulse, it suggests the presence of worms. A deep and slow pulse with an intermittent fever indicates stomach cold; warming it will bring relief.

    The rule states: a child’s pulse is tight in cases of wind convulsions; a deep and slow pulse with food stagnation leads to frequent vomiting. A tense and rapid pulse indicates discord in Qi, while a fast pulse suggests fright preventing spirit from settling. A cold pulse is deep and fine, while a wind pulse is floating. Firm stools that are difficult or prolonged indicate issues. If abdominal pain leads to tight and tense pulses, chaotic pulses are a sign that treatment may be futile. During the time of transformation, the pulse must be chaotic; without treatment, false diagnoses may follow. A single fine pulse with signs of malnutrition indicates the presence of worms, and an uneven pulse size signifies adverse signs. A slow and deep pulse with intermittent fever indicates an internal invasion of stomach cold. Excessive diarrhea with a strong pulse is difficult to treat; careful consideration and examination are necessary.

    Master Yunqi states: Before the age of five, it is unwise to evaluate pulse characteristics, as differentiation is not possible. Only after five years can the distinctions of floating and sinking, fast and slow, be made. According to Qian's writings, the age limit is not strictly bound to five years.[12p]
    Discussion on Children

    From the "Suwen": When the body is hot and dislikes cold, shivering and anxiety ensue, these are signs of a heat condition, belonging to the Shaoyin's fire. If there are severe and straightened limbs with internal urgency and muscle spasms, these are wind conditions, belonging to the Jueyin's wind wood. Children are defined as those above six years of age, and those above eighteen years as youth. Those below six years are not covered by the various channels, which is why infants are difficult to treat when ill, and their conditions cannot be determined. However, children and adults cannot be treated the same way; they require different treatments. Although children are fragile and soft in their bones and flesh after being swaddled, their intestines and stomach are delicate; they can digest milk and food, which helps balance their internal organs, allowing them to remain healthy. Their skin is moist and their muscles and bones are tender, thus when dressed in soft clothing, any blockage may occur, leading to internal heat accumulation. This heat can harm the heart, causing it to suffer from evil heat, resulting in fright. If fright persists, it may turn into convulsions. Generally, illnesses in children are characterized by pure Yang, with an excess of heat and a deficiency of cold.[13p]
    Pediatric Illnesses

    Children suffering from food accumulation, phlegm, and heat, often have issues related to milk. Generally, liver and spleen disorders are prevalent. Children are commonly afflicted with liver issues, where the liver is often excessive and the kidneys are deficient.

    Observation of Form and Color

    The forehead is associated with heart fire, the left cheek with liver wood, the right cheek with lung metal, the nose with spleen earth, and the chin with kidney water. The color purple indicates excessive heat, red signifies exterior pathogenic heat, green suggests fright, white indicates parasites, dark greenish-black points to abdominal pain, white suggests malnutrition, yellow signifies spleen deficiency, yellowish-white with blue lips indicates malaria, yellow suggests food accumulation, dark purple indicates pestilence, and bluish-white suggests liver issues.

    When observing children’s form and color, bluish veins indicate spleen heat generating wind. Red and hot cheeks exhibit conflict, while yellow indicates spleen deficiency. Dark gas with abdominal pain indicates pestilence, and white signifies malnutrition causing weight loss. If encountering dark rings around both eyes, it is as if experiencing a dream.

    To recognize children's symptoms, one must assess their appearance. Yellow skin with thin muscles suggests retention of masses; blue lips and a pale face indicate pain. A dry tongue and scorched lips signal internal heat, while drowsiness with dim vision suggests depleted spleen energy. Clenching hands and pulling feet indicate fright, and malnutrition produces a distended belly.

    Mucus at the corners of the eyes signifies liver heat, while saliva at the mouth indicates spleen cold. Sparse, upright hair indicates blood deficiency, and bubbling edema suggests dampness related to the spleen.[14p]
    Nostrils blackened and charred indicate lung heat, dry ears signify kidney transmission. Elevated chest and short of breath reflect lung inflammation, heat causing the fontanel to swell and sink.

    The child’s spirit suddenly diminishes, their facial skin turns yellowish white and inconsistent. It is likely that dairy and food within cause harm, chilled and greasy foods obstruct the body. Symptoms may lead to bowel sounds and diarrhea, or potentially malaria manifesting. Suddenly swollen, gradually emaciated, signs of phlegm, parasitic ailments, and four symptoms emerge.

    The child's skin turns red, cheeks appearing as if painted with vermilion. How about the effects of wind and cold? The tidal heat comes and goes without notice. It may resemble convulsions requiring treatment, or toxins being expelled. The mouth feels dry, crying with tears like pearls, sleep is sluggish, refusing to nurse.

    Childhood illnesses take various forms, ultimately reliant on visual assessment. Huddled in arms, timid of the cool wind, feeling warm and feverish during sleep. Night crying with fever leads to abdominal pain, gazing straight, convulsions need caution. Long sighs and short breaths hide heat within, phlegm and wheezing surge upward, fire is strong.

    It is essential to identify signs of a child's passing; the fontanel sinks, forming a pit. In the throat, gas and phlegm tug and saw, eyes closed, spirit absent. Lips and gums turn pale white, hands and feet feel icy cold. The crow calls, mouth tight, eyes often rolling, refusing to nurse, and experiencing urinary incontinence, resulting in chaos.[15p]
    Pulse Diagnosis

    For children over one year old, the pulse can be examined. Six beats per breath indicate a balanced state; seven or eight beats suggest excess heat, while one to four beats indicate a slow and weak state. Normally, a child's pulse should have six beats per breath in a balanced manner. Seven to eight beats are often associated with excessive heat, while three to four beats indicate a deficiency of cold diseases. If there are nine or ten quick beats, it resembles the pecking of a sparrow, and one or two movements of the fingers indicate an illness. A slightly cold, tight, and rapid pulse is unmistakably accurate, and the treatment should be clear between tonifying and purging.

    When there is body heat, a floating pulse may indicate the need for sweating; if the body is cold, a fine pulse suggests rest without aggressive treatment. Asthma and cough with a tight and rapid pulse show that medication may be ineffective, while swelling and a fine pulse may indicate pain. For diarrhea that is deep and slow, recovery is uncertain, and for measles with many rapid pulses, treatment is urgent. If there are vomiting and epistaxis (nosebleed) with a fear of floating and surging pulses, and abdominal pain that is deep and subtle, careful inspection is essential.[16p]

    On Treatment Methods

    If the lower legs feel hot, both cheeks are red, there is persistent thirst, the face is flushed, limbs are tossed about, bowel movements are obstructed, urine is yellow, the body is strong and feverish with no signs of retreat, all of these should be treated with cooling remedies. Hot and tonifying medications should not be used.

    Young children should not be given hot medications, with cheeks resembling ripe peaches. Their hands and feet feel hot and fiery; the pulses are floating and chaotic, urine is red and concentrated, bowel movements are stubbornly constipated. They may lift their clothing to drink water, enjoy being in the wind, have persistent thirst, and experience nosebleeds.

    If the lower legs feel cold, the face appears pale, the breath fluctuates between hot and cold, the body often leans against others, the eyes are blue, there is persistent vomiting and diarrhea, and abdominal pain occurs, all of these should be treated with warming tonics. Cooling and purging medications should not be used.

    Young children should not be given cooling medications; their complexion appears pale and listless. The limbs are cold as ice, and the pulses are faint and hidden. They have difficulty digesting milk, often vomit, and their stools resemble duck droppings, occurring frequently. They show signs of weakness, abdominal pain, blue eyes, and prolonged illness may lead to complications.

    For children under one year of age with illness, it is often due to fetal toxins, and it is urgent to detoxify. For those over two years old with illness, it is mostly due to food accumulation, and treatment should aim to alleviate this and tonify the spleen. Other methods are scattered throughout various sections and will not be detailed here.

    If there is an exterior affliction from wind-cold, a dispersing powder can be used. For internal injuries from milk and food causing discomfort, harmonizing and digestive remedies should be administered concurrently. For coughs, the group of herbs known as "Shen Su" can be brewed, and for vomiting and diarrhea, the rectifying formula is the most effective. For shocks causing spasms, “Guangxin” should be used, and the red and green detoxifying methods should not be mixed.[17p]
    Discussion on the Excess and Insufficiency of Prenatal Qi in Knowing Life and Death

    When a child is born, if there is a rupture in the body, it will surely die. If the scrotum is white, it will surely die. If the genitals do not descend, it will die. If there is no flesh in the abdomen, it will surely die. If the cry resembles that of a crow, it will surely die. At the age of one, if the skull bones are opening, teeth and hair have not emerged, limbs are contracted, knees appear like crane joints, and the body is weak and cannot stand, this indicates insufficiency of prenatal Qi, leading to early death. If the muscles are strong, then there is much strength; if the bones are solid, then there is early movement; if the blood is abundant, the body is thin with much hair; if the flesh is sufficient, there are few diseases; if the essence is rich, the child is clever and often laughs and speaks, unafraid of cold or heat; if the Qi is sufficient, there is little hair and a plump body – these all indicate an abundance of prenatal Qi, leading to longevity.

    Examine the Cold and Heat of the Hands

    The tips of the five fingers being cold signifies an inability to withstand shock. If the middle finger is hot, it surely indicates a febrile illness. If the middle finger is cold on its own, it is a sign of smallpox. Boys have their left hand and girls their right; this should be observed carefully.

    Examination of the Three Passages and Hand Tendons in Children[18p]
    Infants aged one month to three years, if they have ailments, must check the pulse at the tiger's mouth, then the index finger's first segment represents the life gate, the second the qi gate, and the third the wind gate. According to ancient texts, if one first contracts a wind gate illness, it is still treatable; however, once it reaches the qi gate, it is certainly difficult to cure.

    When diagnosing hand channels and colors:

    For males, observe the left index finger; for females, observe the right index finger. The first segment of the wind gate is easy to treat, the second segment of the qi gate indicates deeper illness, and the third segment of the life gate suggests death. If the three gates are blue, it indicates shock to the limbs. If they are black, it indicates water-related shock. If they are purple or white, it suggests someone carries shock. Red indicates fear from a dog. Such pulse conditions at the three gates are very serious and signal certain death; other ailments may still be treatable.

    The wind gate appearing blue like a fish spine is easy to treat; this is initial shock. If it is black, it becomes difficult to treat. The qi gate appearing blue like a fish spine signifies consumption and fever; it is easy to treat with a life-preserving formula added with Chai Hu and Huang Qin. The life gate appearing blue like a fish spine indicates weakness and wind evasion affecting the spleen, which is difficult to treat using a golden tablet with Bai Zhu and Fu Ling.

    If the wind gate appears dark blue like a suspended needle, it indicates water shock. If this occurs at the qi gate, it indicates consumption with accumulated heat in the lungs; it should be treated with a life-preserving formula added with lantern heart and bamboo leaves. If the life gate shows five colors, they are all signs of death that cannot be treated.

    If the wind gate appears like the word for water, it indicates phlegm in the diaphragm and stagnation; the treatment should focus on descending. At the qi gate, it indicates shock entering the lungs, causing coughing and a red face; treat with a life-preserving formula. At the life gate, it suggests severe shock accompanied by wind and consumption; use aloe pills. If bypassing the three gates occurs, then treatment should cease.[19p]
    The wind passage resembles the shape of the letter "乙," which is associated with liver shock and is easy to treat. In the air passage, it indicates sudden shock, while in the life passage, the dark blue or black indicates chronic spleen wind, which is difficult to treat.

    The wind passage looks like a curved bug, signifying accumulation of malnutrition disease, with the chest resembling a row of counting beads and the abdomen resembling an inflated pig bladder. In the air passage, it signifies accumulation of filth in the large intestine. In the life passage, it relates to the heart influencing the liver and is difficult to treat.

    The wind passage resembles a ring, indicating hot accumulation in the liver related to malnutrition; in the air passage, it signifies malnutrition entering the stomach, leading to unresolvable vomiting; in the life passage, the malnutrition is challenging to treat.

    If there are irregular patterns, limited to the wind and air passages, treatment is still possible. However, if the life passage is affected, treatment becomes difficult.

    If there are rashes, either blue or black, occurring on the hands, feet, face, or on either side of the face, it is fatal.

    If the pulse patterns curve inward, it indicates air malnutrition. Those affected experience tightness in the abdomen and should be treated with purging.

    If the pulse patterns curve outward, it suggests wind malnutrition. Those affected should be treated urgently for shock.

    If the pulse patterns slant to the right, it indicates fever due to typhus with no appetite and no sweating; treatment should involve "Awakening the Consciousness" powder.

    If the pulse patterns slant to the left, it suggests fever from a common cold accompanied by loss of appetite and sweating.

    A double hook pulse indicates typhus.[20p]
    There are three types of pulses resembling long worms; these indicate injury to hard substances.
    There are pulses with two curves like hooks; these indicate injury to cold substances.
    There is a pulse with one end like a ring, and also one with a single foot; these too indicate injury to cold.
    If there are four or five dots connected on the face, this is certainly a sign of recurrence.
    On the skin of the head or abdomen, if there are wavy lines resembling the character "you" stacked above and below, along with prominent veins, this indicates the presence of toxic food and accumulated shock, which is difficult to treat.
    Another pulse looks like chaotic worms; this represents malnutrition, as well as parasitic infestations, food accumulation, which can be treated successfully. Any pulse that lacks refinement and is unusually thin indicates wind energy, but after addressing the malnutrition, the response should be observed in healthy growth.

    A Song to Distinguish the Colors of Children’s Pulses

    This is applicable for children aged one month to three years.
    Purple indicates wind, red signifies cold damage, blue suggests shock, and white denotes malnutrition.
    Black may arise from evil influence, while yellow indicates accumulated difficulties in the spleen.
    In the tiger's mouth, if there are many chaotic lines, it indicates disharmony in energy.
    The color blue indicates shock and accumulation; what about cholera and diarrhea?
    If there is a dark blue indicating slow shock onset, many issues will arise in the palms.
    If the three gates suddenly open, this illness is certainly a grave condition.[21p]
    Song of Diagnosis

    A cold nose indicates pain; some say it is a rash. A cold ear results from wind-heat conditions. Pulling at the clothing and a warm belly suggest a cold injury; upper heat and lower cold indicate food-related illness.

    Diagnosis Overview

    Shaking the head and rubbing the eyes, liver heat produces wind. Rubbing the eyes with tears suggests heat in the three burners. A runny nose indicates lung cold. Red cheeks and a yellow face indicate wind injuring lung heat. Cholera with vomiting suggests gastric gas injury. Irregular diarrhea indicates gas attacking the intestines. A blue face and frequent yawning signal wind transferring to the liver. Frequent night sweats show internal heat. Cold injury manifests in chills and spasms. Stomach heat causes rashes and injury from cold. Long sighs and grinding teeth signal excessive wind and energy. Lifting the head and shaking indicates a full chest and stomach. Lung congestion harms and results in coughing up blood. Excessive saliva brings wheezing; accumulated heat from wind causes injuries. Painful urination indicates heat accumulating in the bladder. Hernia due to crying signifies internal blockages in the fetus. Milk bumps and spleen lumps arise from external injuries. A sore throat suggests lung heat. Craving dirt indicates spleen lesions. Vomiting phlegm suggests ascendant roundworms. Rectal bleeding indicates injuries from heat and cold. Thirst and mouth sores show heart heat. A yellow face and edema indicate gas uprising. Issues with legs and neck stiffness arise from internal heat. Speech issues and slowed movements signal accumulation harming the fetus. Stiff neck and liver wind arise from energy harming the tongue. Essential medical texts elaborate on disease origins.[22p]
    Listening to Sounds to Know Illnesses

    A sad voice indicates liver illness, a joyful voice indicates heart illness, a slow voice indicates spleen illness, a calling voice indicates lung illness, a heavy voice indicates arm illness, a clear voice indicates gallbladder illness, a short voice indicates small intestine illness, a rapid voice indicates stomach illness, a long voice indicates large intestine illness, a faint voice indicates bladder illness. A sad and slow voice indicates a conflict between liver and spleen diseases, a rapid and faint voice indicates a conflict between stomach and bladder diseases. A thin and broken voice signifies fullness, a light voice signifies deficiency, a heavy and coarse voice signifies wind, a short and thin voice signifies qi, a coarse voice signifies heat, a short and slow voice signifies diarrhea, and a long tied voice signifies dysentery. A full voice indicates blockage.[23p]
    Distinguishing Life and Death

    When a child suffers from wind-heat, with wheezing and shoulder breaths, a slow pulse indicates life, while a rapid pulse indicates death. In cases of diarrhea, if the pulse is floating and large accompanied by abdominal pain, death is certain. In cases of breastfeeding illness, a small and hanging pulse with warm hands and feet indicates life, while coldness indicates death. If a child is bedridden, sweating like pearls but not flowing, that child will die.

    If a child is ill with a sunken chest, dry lips, eyes fixated, cold breath, a lowered head, unable to rise, with limp hands and feet, rigid body, and cold palms, such cases are untreatable. The same applies to those with a disordered pulse. If the eyes roll upwards, this is called "heavenly suspension," and it should be treated with "Yongquan" (a specific point), extinguishing flames. For those unaware of human affairs, moxibustion is advised. If the nails are red, treatment is possible. For heaviness, use "Tongguan San," blowing it into the nostrils, and treat with "Duanming Dan." If the child does not awaken after something enters the nose, do not attempt treatment.

    If the entire body is red, this indicates a lung disorder, and if there is heat in the spleen channel, there is no need for medication. For children with dark rashes on the face and hands, swollen palms without patterns, dark in the "Kan" area, a flat and full "Ren" area, and foul-smelling stools, along with an inverted head, this child will surely die.

    In summary, when examining a child, if they suckle tightly, treatment is easier; if they suckle loosely, treatment becomes more difficult.[24p]

    General Song

    In pediatrics, there are special methods, but in urgent times, it’s hard to know which to use. Sudden wind, fever, and cough with phlegm should not be neglected when taking life-preserving pills. For acute and chronic shocks, the purple gold pill is essential before the rashes appear. For vomiting and diarrhea with abdominal pain, aiding the stomach is advised; sores in the lips and mouth need to neutralize the toxins. For tidal fever, use the Xin Xin powder; for vomiting, excessive use of needles and pills is necessary. Various types of malnutrition can all use aloe, preventing the need for difficult inquiries and painful searches.

    Discussion on Pediatrics

    In the medical path, treating conditions according to the major pulse is particularly challenging, and pediatric cases are even more difficult. This is because children’s organs are delicate, their skin and bones tender, their blood and qi are not robust, their meridians are like threads, and their pulses fine as hairs. They easily fluctuate between deficiency and excess, cold and heat. Furthermore, they cannot speak, point with their hands, or indicate where they are in pain. Thus, it is rare for someone to accurately diagnose their conditions without examining their form and color, listening to sounds, and feeling the pulse to identify the source of the illness and understand their yin and yang, inner and outer, deficiency and excess.

    Tiger Mouth Pulse

    The first section: red stripes indicate shock from birds or external people. A gentle red stripe signals fire shock; black stripes indicate water shock; green stripes represent thunder or four-foot shock; slightly curled hidden green stripes denote urgent wind conditions. The second section: purple stripes indicate shock from malnutrition, blue stripes denote liver malnutrition, white stripes indicate lung malnutrition, yellow stripes represent spleen malnutrition, and black stripes are difficult to treat. The third section: blue-black stripes at the three joints mean passage is blocked, and if they lean towards the nails, it indicates untreatable conditions.[25p]
    Remarkable Effects of Good Remedies
    (Ming Dynasty - Fang Xian)

    Observing the Three Sections and Five Pulses of Children

    Mr. Shui Jian said: Although children are shaped by the dual forces of yin and yang, their energy is not yet complete, so how can one speak of pulses? Only when the transformation and steaming are completed and the energies of yin and yang are sufficient, can one observe the pulse. At the age of childhood, the formation of yin and yang begins. It is said that a boy is called "tiao" at the age of seven, when his original yang energy emerges; a girl is called "chen" at eight, when her yin and yang are fully formed. Therefore, before reaching the ages of tiao and chen, they are referred to as pure yang. After surpassing the tiao and chen ages, they are called children, and only then can the pulse be observed.

    For a child from birth to half a year old, if there is illness, one should quickly examine the forehead, above the brows, and at the hairline, using the ring finger, middle finger, and index finger to gently press. If all three fingers are hot, it indicates a cold condition resulting in nasal congestion and coarse breathing; if all three fingers are cold, it suggests vomiting and diarrhea. If the index finger is hot, the chest is narrow; if the ring finger is hot, there is disharmony with milk and food, leading to illness. After six months, one can begin to observe the pulse at the tiger mouth area. After one year, observe both the tiger mouth and the pulse of one finger. If after five hundred sixty-four days, the steaming is sufficient, only one finger pulse should be observed by pressing with the index finger, rolling it up and down, and dividing into three sections. The term "three sections" here does not refer to cun, guan, and chi. For children, the three sections are: looking at the facial color as one section, the pulse patterns at the tiger mouth as the second section, and the single finger pulse as the third section. The five pulses include pressing on the forehead above and on Tai Chong below, thus combining the three sections to make five pulses. If a child is ill and shows no severe symptoms, it is not necessary to constantly examine the pulse at Tai Chong, as this pulse is crucial for determining life and death.[26p]
    In a person aged seven or eight, a pulse rate of six beats per breath is typical; eight indicates heat, nine indicates wind, five indicates deficiency, four indicates harm, three indicates collapse, two indicates death. A pulse rate of ten suggests illness and fatigue, resulting in a gaunt appearance. If the body is corpulent and pale, with a pulse rate of eleven or twelve, it is termed deficiency, indicating death from wind sickness and a disordered pulse. If the pulse rate is one or two beats per breath, it signifies an absence of pulse, and the person will likely experience cold and eventually die slowly. A pulse rate of eleven or twelve signifies a rapid pulse, with death likely occurring within three months.

    What is one breath? One inhale and one exhale constitutes one breath. Breathing means the release of air and the intake of air, which is referred to as one breath. If the pulse feels hard and urgent, it indicates a blockage; if it is small, weak, and fine, it signifies cold; if light and weak, it indicates heat; if there is a sudden strong pulse, it suggests shock; if the pulse is uneven, it indicates a dire condition. Light and rapid pulses signify heat, while deep and firm pulses indicate cold; an uneven pulse suggests a bad prognosis.

    Rapid pulses indicate tension; light pulses suggest a floating sensation; deep pulses feel firm under pressure; a blocked pulse indicates irregularity; heavy pulses sink deeply; and fine pulses are subtle. An uneven pulse, with variations in strength, signifies a lack of vital energy, and that person is bound to die. The previous scholars have thoroughly detailed the methods of the three divisions and five pulses, noted on the left. Future practitioners must not regard this lightly, as human life is at stake; they should diligently examine with sincere intent, with care and precision. Any mistakes could lead to grave consequences. A physician is responsible for life; must they not be cautious![27p]

    Differentiating the Three Pulses and Symptoms

    When the upper pulse is black, it indicates kidney issues. When the middle pulse is black as well, it suggests lingering symptoms. People are alarmed by this mixed condition, with the eyes often staring, suggesting phlegm accumulation.

    When the lower pulse is black, it signals further alarm, but it’s essential to disperse wind and relieve accumulated heat in the intestines. Upper and lower pulses share the same cause of disturbance, as heat causes blockage and a lack of spirit.

    When the upper pulse is green, it indicates wind in the liver, with straight gazes causing the face to appear greener. The middle pulse corresponds to alarm affecting all four limbs, leading to thirst, restlessness, and confusion. A lower green pulse signifies recurrent alarm roots; relieving heat and manifesting the intestines involves analysis.

    If both upper and lower pulses are green, it is severe, with only one in ten remaining stable. A red upper pulse suggests excessive wind in the lungs, possibly leading to frequent fever and cough. The middle pulse indicates wind attacking the heart, resulting in abdominal pain and frequent diarrhea.

    A lower red pulse reflecting severe shock denotes a need to regulate the heart using divine methods. When the upper and lower pulses are both difficult to treat, wide-eyed and open-mouthed, it indicates danger.

    When the green liver pulse retains its form, closed eyes and body aches signify fragility. In the middle pulse, it points to watery diarrhea and recurring disturbance, with heat causing breathlessness and coughs without respite.

    A lower green pulse might indicate alarm; efficient medicine can disperse wind and mitigate calamity. If both upper and lower pulses are green and generate heat, the limbs feel cold, signaling urgency.

    When the upper pulse appears black, the eyes are wide, with loose stools possibly showing a green hue. When observed in the middle, signs reflect thirst; lower heat seems to yield yellow urine with stable bowels.

    If the lower black pulse reveals accompanying red, frequent diarrhea ensues. Both upper and lower pulses must be evaluated through the extremities; if they feel empty and restless, thirst calls for prompt medical attention.

    Observing the Three Positions of the Pulse and the Five Colors[28p]

    When a red vein is seen at the upper pulse, it indicates a heart disease. It is feared that a purge could lead to deficiency, producing wind and phlegm; both should be treated with Zhenxin pills and Jingfeng powder.

    If the middle pulse is red, it suggests excess wind heat, and one should administer cooling herbs to resolve this.

    If the lower pulse is red, it may indicate fever and obstruction in the large intestine, which is a bad sign.

    A black vein seen at the upper pulse indicates that the kidney pulse is in proper order. If there is obstruction in the large intestine causing wind symptoms, one should administer Zhu Sha ointment.

    A black vein in the middle pulse suggests symptoms of wind but is not necessarily a bad sign; one should dispense Zhong Huang ointment.

    If the lower pulse shows black without any worsening symptoms, one can treat with Xuan Zhuan pills, which will yield recovery. If there is diarrhea, this indicates cold in the intestines, and one should give warming decoctions for the internal organs without changing the treatment.

    If a blue vein is observed at the upper pulse accompanied by reversed limbs and vomiting with added wheezing, it indicates a bad sign. If symptoms of vomiting and wheezing stabilize, it indicates recovery.

    A blue vein in the middle pulse suggests wind attacking the heart, and it should be treated urgently with anti-wind remedies, such as Wu Xi and Zhu Sha ointment.

    If a blue vein at the lower pulse shows no symptoms, it’s unnecessary to treat further.

    Both the upper and middle pulses present similarly: warm limbs indicate harmony; reversed limbs indicate danger.

    If a black vein and dark circles under the eyes are present, with a condition not yet reaching two years, this pulse indicates a presence of symptoms or excessive heat in the large intestine, leading to thirst. If there is no heat or thirst, one should treat with a resolving method. First, dispense Tianzhu yellow powder, then Zhu Sha ointment.

    Disordered black veins indicate abdominal distention as a symptom, or if there is pain below, it suggests accumulation; one should use Xuan Feng pill powder followed by Yun Qi powder to harmonize the stomach qi.

    Disordered red veins indicate agitation, requiring urgent treatment with Zhenxin pills and Da Jing pill powder.[29p]
    The pulse at the middle section indicates sudden changes in weather; avoid using downward-acting medicine, as it may harm the spleen. If sitting leads to vomiting, it is a bad omen; use harmonizing Qi powders to nourish deficiency.

    If on the first day you see red pulse in the three regions, it signifies issues with the five organs. If on the second day the middle pulse is faint or hidden, and only the middle region is observable, it suggests a meteorological influence.

    On the third day, if the three regions are either visible or slightly protruding, it indicates an essence-related condition. If consistently faint, without cycles, it may lead to death in several weeks.

    If the upper part of the left hand has a red pulse returning to the inside, it signifies injury from accumulation, requiring the Tong Wan pills. If it curves to the outside, it indicates an attack by external winds, leading to convulsions; administer the Zhen Xin Wan powder.

    If the middle pulse returns inward, it suggests external wind transforming; use regulating powders to resolve it. A curve outward represents a grave omen.

    If the pulse exceeds the life gate and there are adverse signs outside, it is a bad omen. A chaotic red pulse in the upper region indicates issues from cold; use harmonizing Qi powders.

    If the middle pulse is disordered, it suggests a wind-related heat transmission due to excessive wind; employ Wu Xi ointment to resolve it.

    If the lower region is disordered, immediate warming of the spleen is necessary. If food intake is hindered, it is a bad sign.

    If both sets of finger joints show mingled blue and red, resembling a purple tone without black, it is a grave omen.

    If the upper region pulse is present, a cold illness is likely to cause a cough, requiring a slight release of the exterior.

    If the pulse rises into the middle region, it indicates a wind condition; administer Qing Jin Gao.[30p]
    If one sees the lower gate, frequently retreating is auspicious; not retreating is a sign of misfortune. If a child transmits energy from the Qiguan (气关) to the Mingguan (命关), then treatment can be applied. The secrets above are for the divine physician. Those who have learned from previous sages should carefully ponder these.

    The two immortal figures, Sun and Hua, said: When a child's left hand pulses are observed in the right hand, it is a sign of inversion and evil. Conversely, when the right hand pulses are seen in the left hand, it is also a sign of inversion and bad omen. This defines life and death with Yin and Yang; how much more so with the pulse of the tiger's mouth?

    From ages five to ten, once weaning is done and food is introduced, Yin and Yang are complete, thus a single finger can determine the three gates, measuring with precision akin to the nine indicators of heaven and earth.

    In matters of child illness: the sound of crows, the passing of black stools, diarrhea with green pus, pulling at clothing seams, eyes staring too intently, speech being mumbling, smiling vacantly at others, turning face towards the ground, crying with no tears, eyes lacking luster, limbs lying flat against the ground, refusal of medicine at the mouth, limbs flat on the ground, a change in stools, sweating like beads, pulling eyebrows, biting nails, stretching the body, long sighs, a craving for cold water, legs curled like hooks, persistent stretching, vocal sounds being thunderous, fish-like mouth, sticking out the tongue, lips turning black, prolonged lip redness, unstable breathing, long-standing desire to eat dirt, eyes rolling back, spleen diarrhea changing into red dysentery, and other unexplainable symptoms.[31p]
    Symptoms in Infants Before Three Months Old

    Symptoms include wind drooling, monkey-like convulsions, umbilical wind, pursed lips, coughing, silent noises, wooden tongue, heavy palate, stiff neck, and high chest.

    Pulse Colors

    A pure red pulse indicates a newly acquired illness, characterized by Yang and heat, suggesting the disease is external. A red and purple pulse indicates a transition in disease, suggesting there is heat both internally and externally, or heat alone indicating Yang. A red or purple pulse with hints of blue indicates a chronic disease, characterized by alternating cold and heat, reflecting external changes. A pure blue pulse indicates a prolonged illness, associated with both cold and heat, and is internal and Yin. A blue and yellow pulse suggests a severe transformation to cold, where extreme cold could turn to heat, making treatment difficult; it indicates a vacant cold affecting the five organs, with conflicting Yin and Yang symptoms. A blue and black pulse indicates a critical condition, possibly from a long-standing illness leading to a dark complexion. A black and yellow pulse, especially when showing the yellow, indicates a 90% chance of death, indicating great misfortune.[32p]
    Face

    The face is red, indicating a deficiency of heart qi. Fire is associated with the heart and leads to rising heat, hence this is understood. The cessation of heart function results in death. Symptoms include clenching teeth and manipulating the tongue, a protruding tongue, ulcers in the mouth, a swollen tongue, a constricted throat, a white coating on the tongue, a heavy tongue underneath, a swollen throat, phlegm and saliva bubbling up, resembling a fish’s mouth; these signify a critical and severe condition.

    When the left temple and the angles of the eyes show red veins, it indicates a transformation due to steaming heat, leading to restlessness and crying, with warmth in the head and abdomen, which may subside in a day or two.

    When red veins appear on the Taiyin, it indicates a cold-induced condition, signifying strong heat and nasal congestion.

    Red veins showing on the Wentai indicate a cold-induced condition lasting three days, signifying internal heat and headache.

    If the red veins extend from the Taiyang to the Taiyin, it indicates heat both inside and outside; if also connecting to the Wentai, it signifies intense heat that doesn't resolve; progressing to the Wutai, symptoms may begin to change.

    Red veins at the Yumen suggest conditions of heat and fright, leading to frequent startled movements, excessive chirping sounds, and difficulty sleeping at night.

    Red veins from the forehead to the center of the eyebrows indicate conditions of fright wind and fever. If leading to the Yin Tang, it suggests fright phlegm and spasms with heat, indicating scanty urination.

    Red veins at the Yin Tang suggest accumulated heat in the heart meridian.[33p]
    In the center of the eyebrows, the red veins connect to the Yintang, or there are red shadows. The heart and liver have concentrated heat in the upper jiao, with phlegm and fluids congesting the upper jiao, causing crying and phenomena of fright to arise. There is a protrusion under the left brow, signifying concealed fright, often manifesting as sudden jumps during sleep.

    The red veins at the temples are swollen and protruding, indicating the presence of wind-heat phlegm causing fright, due to rising heat attacking urgently, as there is persistent heat phlegm in the heart and stomach, gradually leading to symptoms of fright wind. Cooling agents should be employed to dispel phlegm and relieve heat to restore calm. If the red veins at the temples lead to the Yintang, the symptoms of fright have been present for many days.

    The red color at the left brow indicates unresolved steaming heat, with heat present in the liver and lungs; it should be treated with agents that clear the lungs and disperse wind-heat while regulating the stomach qi.

    At the Fengchi point, the redness signifies wind-heat in the upper and middle jiao, indicating a potential for convulsions; it is recommended to eliminate wind and transform phlegm.

    At the Quchi point, redness indicates that the lingering wind has transformed and is affecting the organs; there is heat present in the three jiao and frequent relieving is advised. Redness at the Yintang implies heat, fright, phlegm, and dietary issues; if nothing is expelled, it could lead to convulsions.

    Red veins from the Yintang to the root of the nose signify heat in the heart and small intestine, with scanty red urine. From the root of the nose to the nasal column has redness, indicating heat in the heart and stomach, with both urine and stool being red and scanty.

    The redness extending from the Yintang to the upper Zhu indicates accumulated heat in the three jiao, which can be curbed with cooling agents.

    Above the Zhu, red-yellow is stable and free of affliction.[34p]
    The red pulse at the Yimen indicates an external kidney condition caused by wind and warmth, leading to heat and irritability. The red on the face suggests internal agitation and heat.

    The red pulses on the right Taiyang and corners of the mouth are due to the infant's nursing mother suffering from a cold, causing obstructed milk and resulting in issues like milk tumors with wind-heat phlegm. The red pulse on the right Taiyin arises from the mother having a heat illness along with phlegm in the milk, potentially inducing phlegm. The red pulse at Wutai gradually develops into symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea due to fright.

    The red pulse at Fengchi indicates that the mother does not avoid spicy foods or pork and mutton bone soup, possibly leading to toxic milk causing wind. The red pulse at Qichi shows that if the mother has heat and phlegm, even when the child reaches ten years, signs of the illness may still manifest. The heat-phlegm from the mother enters the child's five viscera, resulting in blurred vision and transmitting other diseases. The red pulse at Yimen indicates a kidney qi issue, related to the mother consuming beverages or odd foods, and eating chicken, geese, ducks, fish, garlic, which may lead to different illnesses later on.

    Seven Manifestations

    The pulse is floating, slippery, full, tight, and surging.
    The floating pulse indicates wind and loss of blood, the slippery pulse suggests discernible vomiting and clear downward movement. The tight pulse indicates tension while the surging pulse typically signifies heat.

    Eight Li

    The pulse is slightly sunken, slow, soft, retracted, moist, and weak.
    A slow and cold pulse with slight hardness indicates distress, while the hard pulse suggests stagnation of bad blood and moisture. The retracted pulse indicates pain from stagnation and cold, while the weak pulse suggests a subsequent deficiency character.[35p]
    Nine Patterns

    Long and short pulses, vacuity and fullness, rapid and slow, all indicate different conditions. A long pulse suggests yang deficiency in the triple warmer; a short pulse indicates that food is not digesting properly in the chest. A vacuous pulse often brings about surprise and confusion, while a rapid pulse signifies a critical situation from which it is hard to escape. A knotty pulse indicates qi stagnation leading to emaciation, while a firm pulse suggests vigorous heat as if the bones are being scorched. If the pulse is moving, it suggests a risk of blood loss and fragility; a fine pulse indicates sourness in the limbs and a tendency toward weakness.

    Observation of Infants

    Firstly, observe the two eyes for vitality; secondly, check the clarity and loudness of the voice; thirdly, examine the top of the head; fourthly, assess the appearance; and fifthly, look at the hair.

    1. The two eyes gather the essence of the five organs and house the spirit of the whole body. If the pupils are dark and full of luster, and the spirit is bright and lively, it suggests the child will live long and have few illnesses, recovering easily even if they become sick. If the whites of the eyes are excessive and the pupils are dull or yellow, this indicates a weakness in their constitution, leading to many ailments.

    2. A loud and clear voice shows robust qi from the five organs, aiding the child in growing strong. If the child is born without crying, or if the voice does not emerge, this suggests a blockage in the yin passages of one or two organs, indicating timidity and frailty; or if the sound is feeble or like a weak whisper, this signifies that the child will not live long and will be difficult to raise.

    3. The crown of the head relates to the mother’s qi and blood; a firm and strong crown indicates good nourishment for the child. If the mother suffers from illness or her qi and blood are weak, the child's crown will be soft and insubstantial. The back of the head relates to the father’s essence; if rich and substantial, it allows the child’s back of the head to be strong and well-nourished.[36p]
      If a father's vital energy is insufficient and he excessively indulges in wine, the child may have a weak and unsteady head and will also have a short life. If both parents are timid, their offspring will also not live long. In such cases, the parents will not reach a long life. The front and rear points are referred to as the "trust gates," with the Daoists calling it the "mud pill." The rear trust is known as the "brain top gate." The center of the head is also called the "hundred meetings point." Hua Tuo described facial readings in great detail. The front and rear trust, as well as the hundred meetings, if open and vacuous, are referred to as "uncovered skull."

    Fourth, in terms of appearance, a wide mouth and pointed nose, with raised eyebrows and bright eyes, indicate a child who grows easily and possesses strong blessings. Conversely, a small mouth and bent nose, with a concave and wrinkled brow, may lead to strange traits in the child, resulting in either poverty or early death — this is difficult to decipher.

    Fifth, hair is the residue of blood. If the mother's blood and energy are abundant, the hair will be black and lustrous. If the mother's blood is deficient, leaking, or failing, with irregular menstruation, or if she indulges in excessive drinking and debauchery, or if there are disturbances from the womb, the child's hair will be yellow and withered, leading to ailments like sores or fevers.

    In observing a child’s spirit, color, and pulse, all fall within these five aspects. It’s impossible to see them all, but if the child’s eyes are spirited and their voice is clear, this may ensure their well-being. This is the secret technique passed down by the Wang family of Han Dong.[37p]
    A Brief Treatise on Pediatric Medicine

    In pediatric medicine, the discipline is called "silent discipline." The child cannot speak, and the pulse cannot be measured; one must rely solely on their appearance and color, exhausting all thoughts to apply treatment. Therefore, those who are skilled in nurturing children treat them as if raising a dragon for careful care; those who are unskilled treat them as tender calves and cherish them. The more one loves them, the more harm one inadvertently causes. At times, their head may feel warm but their feet are cold; suddenly, they cry a lot but refuse milk. A small error can lead to a huge loss. This specialized pediatric medicine serves to address what conventional practices fail to cover.

    The intestines and stomach are fragile and easily harmed by food; the muscles and bones are weak and easily attacked by wind and cold. Parents should be aware and carefully observe the child's condition. Thick and heavy clothing may hinder warmth and drain vital energy; excessively forcing milk or food merely disrupts the spleen and harms the stomach. Hearing unusual sounds or seeing unfamiliar objects can lead to neglect in prevention; it is necessary to provide a secure environment and limit excessive outings, avoiding over-attentiveness.[38p]
    Without waiting, one takes action and rejoices in their growth; when idle, one laughs and is called wise. But one day, illness arises, and the hearts of parents are troubled. Distrusting doctors, they instead believe in shamans, seeking ghosts rather than medicine. Thus, the neglect of human affairs is blamed on fate.

    To observe one's complexion, one must first discern the parts of the body. The left cheek belongs to the Green Dragon and is associated with the liver; the right cheek belongs to the White Tiger and is related to the lungs. The forehead, high and separated, embodies the heart’s fire, while the lower regions correspond to the kidney's water. The nose is at the center of the face, connecting to the spleen. By observing the colors that manifest, one can understand the origins of diseases. Moreover, the spleen corresponds to the lips, the lungs to the nose, the tongue reflects the heart, and the eyes signify the liver's fluids. The stomach flows to the lower jaw, while the kidneys open through the ears. The nails are remnants of the tendons, with the spleen governing them, while hair reflects the surplus blood, under the kidney's dominion. The spleen governs the limbs, and the kidneys connect to the teeth. If any of the internal organs decline, then the corresponding parts will surely weaken first.[39p]
    Able to discern shape and color, resembling a beam striking a bell; if I am unaware of my omens, it’s like a stone thrown into water. All that is observed externally can reveal the internal. The red color signifies market heat, the blue color exposes and startles the heart. Like the blackness of coal, it indicates malice; like the yellow of oranges, it represents spleen deficiency. White signifies illness and exhaustion, purple indicates acute heat. Blue hides the mouth corners, making it difficult for the physician Bian Que to treat; black obscures the sun, making it impossible for physician Lu to cure. The longevity marked by red light often produces pus and blood, while the blue color found at the root of the mountains frequently heralds disasters. To discern colors in order to understand causes, one cannot merely follow diagrams to seek steeds.

    The Vermilion Bird pierces through the double pupils, fire enters the watery lands; the Azure Dragon coils around the four whites, the liver sits in the lung's position. One must be cautious of those with diarrhea accompanied by yang, and one should fear those with coughs dragging in blue. The belly pain emerges deep, the face remains pale with pursed lips; when a wind of fright is about to break, the cheeks become red first and the eyes bulge.[40p]
    The flames burn brightly, feeling the chill of the wind outside; the golden essence floats, harboring hidden ailments within. Sometimes yellow, sometimes white, lingering heat; both blue and red, urgent with wind evils. Observing carefully leads to proper treatment. The cries of crows and the mouths of fish waste effort and thought; flesh bends and skin dries, laboring in vain.

    The complexion changes, the appearance alters. When energy wanes, the jaw becomes a pit; when blood weakens, hair on the head stands like a tuft. Eyes produce tear-like mucus, the liver wind clouds the sight; the mouth drips saliva, the spleen is cold and stagnant. The face appears hollow, likely to swell and wheeze; if the brows furrow, then abdominal pain leads to weeping. Worms emerge, the spleen and stomach begin to fail; sores hide above, while the lower intestines suffer first. If one remains dazed and unhealed, even deities would be of no help!

    The hands resemble claws, startled by the onset of wind; the face is as if painted with vermilion, the heart fire already blazing.[41p]
    I enjoy sitting and lying down in the cold, troubled by the heat’s assault; I stretch and contract out of fear of the wind and chill. My belly is large while my feet are small; my spleen wants to be at ease but instead degenerates. My eyes are wide open and my mouth agape, the situation is dire and I am destined to perish. Playing with my tongue burns my spleen, relieving my head and exhausting my kidneys. A heavy tongue and a wooden tongue suggest heat accumulating in the heart and spleen; suffocating breaths indicate real fire surging in the liver and lungs. When the gums are swollen and exposed, it surely means dental decay; if I nurse with slackness, it often relates to food stagnation. My lips are dry and parched, and my intestines rumble freely. Nighttime crying falls into four categories, changing with the seasons throughout the year. My heart is hot and longs to speak but cannot; my spleen is weak, making me lethargic at all times. Those who lose their voice after illness have weak kidneys; coughing without a voice indicates lung atrophy. If there is abdominal pain with a clear watery discharge, it suggests worms; if there is belly pain with foul-smelling stools, it points to accumulation. Frequent puckering of the mouth reflects a weak spleen, while a long, stretched tongue signifies fiery ardor.[42p]
    The turtle's chest is swollen with fire in the lungs; the turtle's back signifies wind in the kidneys entering the marrow. Dryness and darkness in the nose indicate excessive fire diminishing metal; a large abdomen with blue veins suggests strong wood causing the earth to collapse.

    Red tumors and sores are all consequences of lingering toxic conditions; vomiting and diarrhea, as well as dysentery, are due to the obstruction of accumulated food. Those who cannot suckle experience heat in the heart and spleen; those who wish to lie face down have fire steaming their intestines and stomach.

    A liking for light indicates heat in the heart; a craving for earth shows a heat condition in the spleen. Abdominal pain from cold invasion and mouth sores suggest heat accumulation. Navel wind is to be avoided during adolescence, while fire sores are to be feared at the age of one.

    Surprise stemming from internal heat leads to convulsions caused by phlegm. Those who experience vomiting and diarrhea with depleted energy are in danger; those with dysentery and reduced appetite will certainly suffer. Surprise originates from the heart, while wind arises from the liver.

    Symptoms may present on either side, indicating the direction of the condition; medicine should be administered based on whether the illness is deficient or excessive. Sudden surprise arises from deep accumulated heat, wherein cooling methods are more suitable; chronic surprise after a major illness requires warming and tonifying treatments.[43p]
    The head shakes and the eyes dart while breathing is labored; the skilled doctor cannot heal. The mouth is bound, the nose flares and the feet are cold; what use are divine elixirs? Those who close their eyes lack a soul, and those who shout in madness attract many woes. Those unaware of their intake and output will surely meet Yama; those who exacerbate their discomfort will ultimately return to the wilds.

    Having understood the symptoms, next comes the knowledge of adjusting and treating. To clear fetal toxins, use licorice and coptis; for food accumulation, use atractylodes and bitter orange. Sudden fright with convulsions should be treated with red-dispelling methods; chronic fright with spasms requires replenishing the middle and boosting energy. Gather the holy to expel dampness, and prepare for urgent treatment of accumulation.

    The Dragon-Holding Pill transforms phlegm and calms fright; the Stomach Spirit Pill nourishes the kidneys and opens the appetite. Nightly crying must retreat heat and clarify the heart; evening heat should nourish blood and elevate energy. Regulate to stop diarrhea with fragrant coptis and control dysentery. If accumulated heat is not cleared, the Cool Fright Pill is highly effective; for deep-seated cold that is hard to treat, the Spleen Nourishing Pill holds the greatest secret.

    Phlegm and fire attacking within is treated with the Three Huang Pill; undigested water and grains require just one golden pill.[44p]
    Chai Ling treats malaria, while Yue Chan alleviates bloating. Tide heat corresponds with golden blossoms, and coughs are soothed with precious fluids. For sores and scabs, use sesame; for red tumors, cooling medications. For those who vomit and thirst, Bai Zhu can be given; for those who are agitated and thirsty, Yi Yuan is the best. Rashes can be detoxified, and abdominal pain can be attributed to spleen accumulation. For nosebleeds and coughing blood, use an infusion of plantain; for heavy and coated tongues, acupuncture is needed. If mouth ulcers do not heal, cleanse the heart; for abdominal bloating and loss of appetite, regulate the stomach. The five wringing techniques treat wheezing, while the four Ling formulas promote water excretion. Counteracting jaundice and reducing swelling can be managed with adjusted stomach formulas; breaking accumulations and calming parasites requires the collected wisdom of the saints. Generally, infants are prone to both deficiency and excess. The key is to maintain balance in treatment, ensuring that replenishment and drainage do not exceed their doses. One should especially avoid Ba Niu and refrain from excessive use of mineral substances. Spicy heat disperses by consuming yin, while bitter cold destroys yang and damages the stomach. If encountering food stagnation, resolve it without delay; if faced with deficiency and weakness, supplementation is most urgent. A short delay can lead to exhaustion and decline.[45p]
    Treatise on Caring for the Young and Guarding the Heart

    In the realm of medicine, the treatment of infants is the most challenging. Their digestive system is delicate and easily harmed by milk and food, their bones are tender and susceptible to wind and cold. They are quick to become weak or robust as if by turning the hand, and the response to treatment can vary; sometimes, one must nourish or drain with the utmost care. Salty flavors often act on the kidneys, while sour tastes support the liver. Bitter flavors harm the stomach and chill it, while pungent flavors move to the lungs and create dryness that damages the essence. One seeks balance and moderation, avoiding extremes in taste.

    In cases of illness, beware of dizziness and avoid toxic remedies; treatment should be appropriate to the situation and based on what is effective. When recognizing a central ailment, prioritize the root cause. If one rashly resorts to herbal decoctions, it may lead to grievous consequences. This reflects the skilled practitioner’s commitment to preserving life, while a good doctor’s judgment is proven through the cure of broken bones.

    I have heard that there are no fixed rules in medicine, only observations of symptoms; do not administer potions without thorough understanding. Those who are ill must be careful in choosing their treatments, and doctors should focus on ensuring recovery. Treat illness as if it were your own, and do not be greedy for personal gain.[46p]
    First, observe the circulation of Qi and the subtle harmony of Yin and Yang; then, examine the appearance and demeanor, grasping the trends of fortune and misfortune. In spring and summer, Yang prevails and the bitterness of cold can be utilized, as evidenced by a person's vitality; in autumn and winter, Yin prevails and warmth can alleviate the suffering, reflecting the labor and illness of individuals. If one warms and restores, then one can counteract the cold and expel. When the Seven Spirits disperse and the Five Organs weaken and collapse, even if one diligently checks the pulse, what remedy exists for the world? It may lead to premature demise and incur divine wrath. Thus, in case of fetal distress, one must urgently detoxify; for food stagnation, the benefit lies in digesting it. Treatment is divided into two methods, and efficacy can be complete. When the swaddling is unsettled, simply adjust the mother; if the infant does not crawl well, then strengthen its vitality. Alas, the balance of the stomach and intestines cannot tolerate medicinals or stones; there is a subtlety in the Qi and blood that is weak and requires gradual nurturing. Treatment is not undertaken lightly; illness can strike suddenly. Like guarding a flickering candle, the heart must remain vigilant; like treasuring a precious pearl, one must focus earnestly. Medicine can augment fate; one should not bring shame to family traditions. Moreover, when illness arises, heat emerges; when heat arises, anxiety follows.[47p]
    Some treat heat with heat, while others attack heat with cold. When heat is superficial, herbs like mulberry and ramie can relieve the muscles and can be ingested; when heat is internal, herbs like gentian and scutellaria can eliminate toxins and must be decocted urgently. For accumulated heat, nothing compares to gathering the sages' wisdom; for empty heat, it’s best to adjust the vital essence.
