It is crucial to understand the pulse and complexion, and not to recklessly administer prescriptions. Missteps can lead to lifelong ailments or shorten an infant's lifespan. Treating lightly can aggravate a condition, and actions alone cannot resolve problems. Simply entrusting oneself to fate without careful examination leads to misfortune. Past mistakes remain as warnings for future actions. The soul wanders in the fields, its cries resonate in the depths of springs. Given these reasons, whose fault is it? Alas! Even ants can cross bridges, and sparrows can escape nets. How much more so for the essence of all things, which is not to be valued less than a lowly insect. Ignorance of caution leads to hasty recklessness. Compassionate conscience is like seeing someone fall into a well; studying the teachings of the sages is essential, as if not reaching the water source. One must be at ease yet vigilant, knowing peace by understanding danger. Evidence follows in various forms, and treatment must not be one-sided.[48p]
    Regulate the transformation of essence and preserve true vitality. It is better to be adept in temple rituals than in assault; it is better to act slowly than to rush. Planting apricots forms a grove, following in the footsteps of Dong Feng; planting oranges by the famous well reflects the legacy of Su Dan today. Alas, chronic leakage leads to dysentery, long-term accumulation results in ulcers, persistent fever causes distension, and excessive fright leads to convulsions. If one has not lingered yet, treatment should be swift; if diseases are already evident, treatment should be gradual. For secretive blockages in the intestines and stomach, prompt expulsion is essential; for deficiencies in qi and blood, swift nourishment is required for stabilization. External toxins must be urgently attacked, lest they enter the abdomen; the urgent dispelling of surface pathogens should not be allowed to transmit again. Thus, I would proceed slowly and with care, fearing that haste may lead to complications. Just as one swallows medicine, one must guard against excess; when treating somewhat serious conditions, do not overstretch one’s capabilities. The wise always consider potential missteps; those who have died cannot be restored to wholeness. Rather than regret what has already occurred, it is better to be cautious about what has yet to happen. If one seeks fish and rabbits, one must protect the reed and hoof. If many methods are employed to treat diseases, three reflections upon these words are advisable!

    Treatment of Children

    For a red face and fever, administer cool medicine; for yellow and white fever, use Stomach Ling. For body heat and constipation, administer the Three Huang; for weak and feverish children, gather the Holy Spirit. For transformation and evaporative heat, use the pressure method; for convulsions, direct the red to swallow the green. For diarrhea, use one pill of Stomach Ling; for heat-related diarrhea, the Jade Dew Powder should be taken together. For cold diarrhea, the Regulating Center Pill can be consumed; for thirst, the White Atractylodes Powder generates fluids. Dysentery can be treated with the Harmonizing and Scenting Powder; malaria can be alleviated by nourishing the spleen, allowing the malaria to naturally resolve. For coughs, the Jade Liquid dispels phlegm and qi; swelling can be treated with Stomach Ling to guide it to the heart. For sores and scabies, Black Sesame Pills are the best, and nourishing the spleen is most crucial for protecting infants. For roundworms, use the White Pill; make sure to give precise instructions on temporary medications.[49p]
    Observing Tiger Mouth Patterns

    Modern practitioners focus on the patterns of the tiger’s mouth, examining the wind, qi, and life conditions. Wind conditions indicate light illnesses, while qi conditions indicate severe issues; if life conditions are poor, death is imminent. Blue signifies shock, red represents heat, and black indicates malevolent forces; one must carefully observe the clouds to assess the severity.

    Pulse Method

    For children, a single finger divides into three positions, with six beats indicating the pulse; seven to eight beats signify heat, while three to four beats suggest a slow, weak, or cold condition. A firm and balanced pulse indicates health, while a thin, weak, or slow pulse suggests illness.

    Miscellaneous Conditions

    When children eat dirt, heat in the spleen is countered with yellow purging methods. Intermittent administration of divine remedies is crucial, as it helps counteract the effects of malnutrition. If a child sleeps with a pale face, it indicates heat in the heart; treat it with Dao Chi San to cool and expel heat. If a child has frequent pale urine resembling rice wash, administering Wei Ling Salt Soup is recommended, followed by several doses of Jie You decoction. For children with green stools, it indicates heat in the liver channel; using Xie Qing Wan is remarkably effective. If the stools are dry and yellow, it suggests heat in the spleen; one may find that Xie Huang San is an extraordinary remedy.[50p]
    Water Mirror Formula

    The operation of yin and yang brings about the formation of men and women. Once the nine orifices and four limbs are divided, the five viscera and six bowels are born. Each part is distinct, and distinguishing between order and disorder can be difficult. If one relies solely on the fluctuations at the pulse point, it can lead to disastrous outcomes in children.

    One must clarify the tiger's mouth, discern the three gates, and carefully analyze medicinal usage to avoid mistakes. Up to the age of three, only the tiger’s mouth should be examined, with boys on the left and girls on the right, at the second finger. The first segment is called the Wind Gate; if the pulse shows initial signs, it indicates sickness. The second segment is the Qi Gate; if the pulse is detected here, treatment is difficult. The third segment is the Life Gate; if the pulse is evident, it signifies death.

    One should also distinguish colors; if the three gates are blue, it indicates surprise in the four limbs; if they are red, it points to watery aversion; if they are black, it signifies shock. Purple indicates diarrhea, while yellow suggests thunderous surprise. If the pulse at the three gates is unobstructed, it is a sign of imminent danger; otherwise, the illness can be treated. A pattern of either blue or red, with a line-like stripe, indicates damage from food and heat-induced surprise. If both sides are the same, it signals simultaneous surprise and accumulation.

    If there are three or if it disperses, it shows wind phlegm from the lungs or indicates a dry cough with sound. Blue indicates cold damage and cough, while fiery red indicates diarrhea. A combination of black indicates diarrhea, while predominant blue indicates more white diarrhea, and predominant red points to more red diarrhea, accompanied by a purple shade that adds thirst but is not false. Disordered pulse patterns at the tiger's mouth signify disharmony in the stomach qi.

    Indeed, when color is observed in the pulse patterns—be it yellow, red, purple, or blue—this indicates that the illness is severe, with colors capable of changing according to the severity of the affliction.[51p]
    If the color is like yellow and red, the abundance of red turns to purple; if the color is red and purple, the abundance of purple turns to green; if the color is purple and green, the abundance of green turns to black; if the color is green and black, arriving at pure black, it cannot be treated.

    There are also distinctions in the shapes of the pulse: for the long pearl shape, it indicates accumulated damage and stagnation, causing abdominal pain, and difficulty digesting cold and hot foods; for the snake shape, it indicates disharmony at the center, accumulated qi attacking, organs in disarray, and dry heaving; for the outgoing snake shape, it indicates spleen deficiency with cold accumulation leading to diarrhea, causing the spirit to feel lethargic and sleepy. The reverse bow shape indicates the invasion of cold and hot evil energy, with heaviness in the head and eyes, the heart disturbed and weary, cold in the limbs, and red urination. The outward bow shape indicates phlegm-heat causing mental confusion, presenting symptoms of heat, shock, and food wind convulsions. The spear shape indicates strong phlegm-heat producing wind, causing convulsions and shocks. The fishbone shape indicates startled phlegm-heat. The water character shape indicates shock and accumulated heat causing agitation, the spirit feeling lost and heavy, night crying with excessive phlegm, and mouth twitching. The needle shape indicates heat affecting the heart and lungs, extreme heat giving rise to wind, causing fright and discomfort, with lethargy and loss of appetite, and strong phlegm leading to twitching. The penetrating pulse of the shooting finger indicates four symptoms of wind, phlegm, and heat, all concentrated in the chest and diaphragm without dispersing. The penetrating pulse of the shooting nail indicates wind shock and adverse conditions, with the shock transmitted into the meridians. When wind and heat arise, the mortality rate is one in ten, making it difficult to treat. These thirteen pulse shapes all have varying degrees of severity; observing their disease roots will clarify their symptoms.[52p]
    Tang's Method of Observing the Tiger Mouth Pulse

    When a child is born until the age of five, their blood and qi are not yet stable, and their breathing may be excessive. One must observe the pulse color at the tiger mouth to discern the true nature of the illness. For boys, check the left hand, and for girls, the right hand. The left hand corresponds to yang, which is dominant in boys; the right hand corresponds to yin, which is dominant in girls. However, both men and women possess both yin and yang in their bodies, and both hands should be examined. The patterns on the left hand indicate issues with the heart and liver; the patterns on the right hand indicate issues with the lungs and spleen. Understanding this information allows for adaptability in diagnosis.

    For initial cases of frightful wind, the pattern at the tiger mouth may appear red, often more so at the initial phase. If it progresses to the middle phase, the color turns bright red and purple. If the illness continues to worsen, the color becomes purple-blue, signaling deeper illness. A pattern that is blue-black with disordered pulse lines indicates serious ailment. If pure black is observed, it signifies a critical and untreatable condition.[53p]
    Generally, red indicates mild wind-heat, while bright red denotes severe wind-heat. Purple suggests sudden heat, and green indicates sudden accumulation. When green and red are equally present, it signifies both sudden accumulation and wind-heat, suggesting an urgent need to address sudden wind symptoms. If there is a pale purple with green, characterized by movements back and forth, it indicates slow onset of wind symptoms. In cases where purple threads, green threads, and black threads are subtly mixed, appearing intermittently, it indicates a chronic spleen wind condition.

    If the pulse pattern starts at the yin gate and does not reach the mao gate, the illness is relatively easy to treat; however, if it connects to the mao gate, the condition is difficult to treat. If it connects from the yin gate to the mao gate and then invades beyond the chen gate, the prognosis is extremely poor, with a one in ten chance of recovery.

    If the pulse pattern is small or short, there is no harm in examining the illness. If the pulse waves curve inward, while the illness may be severe, the condition shows conformity and can still be treated with effort. However, if the pulse waves bow outward and are closely linked to the nail, it should not be reversed. When the pulse at the three gates appears like flowing pearls or fragmented rice, with three to five points connected, manifesting on the face or body, the situation is particularly dire.[54p]
    Distinguishing the Patterns of Pulse in the Tiger's Mouth

    Yellow, formless, indicates the pulse of tranquility. Red, if similarly formless, also signifies a peaceful pulse. Patterns resembling earlier forms indicate illness. They change in sequence, beginning with a dot, gradually increasing in the qi gate with more pulse lines, reaching the life gate when the condition becomes critical. Pure black is distinct and cannot be treated.

    On the left, if there are red lines resembling lines, it indicates fever accompanied by shock. On the right, if there are double lines resembling those on the left, it is a sign of spleen injury with shock accumulation. If the ends of the lines resemble a trident, it suggests lung qi producing phlegm that manifests at night. The blue also corresponds to cold damage but is simply empty red producing leakage.

    Identifying blue lines on the fingers indicates sudden fright. The blue pulse in the tiger's mouth indicates fright from pigs, dogs, or horses. Black suggests shock from water, while red indicates fright in adults. Purple often leads to diarrhea, whereas yellow signifies fright from thunder. Curved back wind greatly intensifies; bow-shaped patterns indicate food reverse.

    One can discern the shape only by observing the intersection of fingers. For children over three years old, if gravely ill or in critical condition, one often observes black coloring around the nails, mouth, and nose. This indicates an absolute pulse where the spirit is trapped, and the condition is extremely severe; even with skilled doctors, recovery is virtually impossible.[55p]

    General Treatment

    Children have a pure Yang constitution, and both Yin and Yang must not be harmed. They often carry a little hunger and coolness; such children are easy to nurture. Generally, the spleen is often insufficient, while excess liver energy must be guarded against. Neutral medicine, neither cold nor hot, is best; it is essential to avoid reckless and violent treatments.

    Why are children difficult to treat? Historically, it is referred to as the "mute disease." The pulse cannot be observed easily, and the child cannot express their illness. Parents are often anxious, and physicians conduct many tests with sincerity. It is challenging to prescribe medicine confidently when faced with such uncertainty.

    Treatise on the Forehead, Center of the Brow, and Mountain Root

    When the forehead is red, hot, and dry, a blue color may indicate liver wind. A green hue at the center of the brow signifies fear, resulting in redness due to fire. If suddenly black qi appears, it is a result of external evil influencing the body. A faint green shade at the mountain root suggests that shock can double the severity. If this area is still red, restlessness will definitely ensue.[56p]
    On the Decay of Years

    The aging years quietly turn yellow as the proper hue, if evenly distributed, face untimely misfortune. Suddenly, black represents dysentery's threat, with cholera's violent yellow vomit seen deep.

    On the Arch of the Mouth

    The arch of the mouth appears blue, indicative of shock when eating, with much yellow leading to reverse vomiting and red dysentery manifestations. Nighttime restlessness and crying show a blue color indicating good fortune, whereas prolonged illness with red brows signals certain death.

    On the Wind and Qi Pools at the Mandibles

    The wind and qi pools display yellow reverse vomiting, with anxiety and cries revealing a bright red hue. The two mandibles can also appear red as buds, suggesting that heat in the lungs is not without reason.

    On the Eyes

    The whites of the eyes show blue due to liver wind; should they turn yellow, it indicates stagnation. Observing black in the pupils with yellow trace reveals the source of the severe cold illness.

    On the Nose

    The nose tip is slightly yellow, balancing with a red-white hue; deep yellow dryness leads to a hazardous black indicating difficulty in survival. A shortened philtrum suggests vomiting due to dysentery, while darkened lips indicate worms leaning towards danger.

    On the Mouth

    The mouth's natural redness suggests balance, while dryness denotes spleen heat generating a yellow accumulation. White indicates blood loss, with black encircling the mouth; a blue-black hue signifies shock from wind leading to certain death.

    On the Temples

    The temples appear blue, indicative of initial shock, while red brings forth the onset of distress. To understand the signs of impending death, one sees that blue marks the beginning of influence on the ears.

    On the Face[57p]
    If both cheeks appear yellow, it indicates phlegm excess; a greenish color suggests a conflict between hot and cold. A red face in cases of cold damage suggests urinary issues; thus, details regarding the two cheeks should be thoroughly examined.

    When facing a child's ailments, first observe their shape and color, then proceed to pulse examination. The overall facial color can indicate various conditions: a blueish hue points to fear or an imbalance of energy; a reddish tint indicates phlegm accumulation or restlessness; yellowness suggests food blockage leading to digestive issues; paleness points to weak lung energy, resulting in excess discharge or diarrhea; a blackish hue indicates critical issues with internal organs.

    A blue face with blue eyes indicates liver ailments; a red face reflects heart issues; a pale face relates to lung conditions; a yellow face corresponds to spleen problems; and a black face indicates kidney concerns. First, distinguish which organ is affected; next, assess their balance of energy, the state of their prenatal vitality, and the conditions of yin and yang. It's crucial to address any excess or deficiency effectively. Understanding the connections between the internal organs and their exterior manifestations is key for skilled practitioners.[58p]
    Secret of Raising Infants by Wan Quan (Ming Dynasty)

    Essay on Subtlety

    The field of medicine is vast, and pediatrics is the most challenging. Just as the shoots of grass are precious in their nurturing, so too must we be cautious in preserving the sprouts of silkworms. When the blood and qi are not fully developed, the pulses cannot be diagnosed; when the spirit is not awakened, the infant cannot speak. Truly seeking from the heart, one must carefully observe the face. If one grasps the essentials, they can wield the forces of creation with masterful hands; if one does not comprehend the purpose, they merely extract phrases from a fragmented text.

    If care is neglected, illness will arise. The head should be cool while the back must be warm; do not overfeed, and do not dress in too much fabric. The intestines and stomach are delicate, and excessive nursing can cause accumulation; if the spirit is timid and weak, strange sights and sounds can induce convulsions. Alas, kind mothers, being overly indulgent, and mocking those with clumsy methods, make mistakes with porridge and pills. They suppress the vital energy of growth, jeopardizing the childhood years. Crying out on the hills and fields is futile, and praying for relief at altars is pointless.

    To recognize symptoms is crucial, and knowledge of life and death is essential. It does not lie near the fingertips, but relies on the face in between. When heart fire ascends, one can observe at the crown; when kidney water descends, one should observe at the soles. The right cheek is gold and pertains to the lungs, the left cheek is wood and pertains to the liver. The spleen's territory is between the nose and the bridge. Blue indicates fright and red signifies heat; yellow represents accumulation and white signals dysentery. Like the black of coal, it points to malice; like the purple of ochre, it indicates an invasion of wind and cold.

    If the prenatal constitution is weak, the hair will be sparse and the head soft; if the constitution is robust, the flesh will be ample and the bones strong. If the nature is calm, there will be little laughter; if the spirit is weary, there will be much sleep.[59p]
    Heat in the lungs causes turbid mucus to accumulate in the nose; cold in the spleen leads to clear saliva stagnating in the jaws. The eyes are linked and speak of liver wind; the pupils gaze straight, reflecting the flame of the heart's fire. When energy is insufficient, the spirit sinks; if it rises, it indicates heat. Excess blood gives a flushed face, while a pale yellow complexion indicates deficiency.

    Those who move slowly show weak kidneys; those who cry frequently are troubled at heart. A hot spleen causes tongue movements, while a strong liver results in clenched fists. Hair standing on end signals the gradual rise of consumption; a cracking head suggests a possible collapse. Skin tightens while flesh withers, signifying a loss of vital energy and an impending departure; an elevated nose and retracted lips show that the essence of grains has been cut off and is difficult to regain. A red worm enters the eye, no need to consult Lu Bian; a green snake coils around the mouth, no need to ask about the divine pill!

    Each organ has its symptoms, which can be understood in a word. The liver governs wind, causing crying and frustration; the heart controls heat, leading to palpitations and yawning. The lungs govern qi, resulting in wheezing, coughing, and sneezing; the spleen governs feelings of heaviness, causing vomiting, diarrhea, and desire for sleep. Only the kidneys are inherently deficient, being connected to life. The liver often has excess, which generates wind; the spleen is frequently insufficient, leading to deficiency disorders. Wood overpowering earth leads to prolonged diarrhea and spasms that cannot be treated; fire affecting metal causes persistent coughs that result in a debilitating condition.

    Within a month, the umbilical wind is most dangerous; within a century, phlegm and coughs are particularly difficult. There is no condition more perilous than a mid-illness crisis; no urgency greater than flowing dan (a type of poison). If transformation is exhausted during the year, it must be measured by the days. If convulsions arise in a timely manner, it is hard to depend on days for relief. Those who suffer will groan; those who lose what they desire will sigh in despair.[60p]
    During the day there is constant shouting, a sign of heat in the liver; at night there is much weeping, indicating cold in the spleen.

    Those born with illness suffer from fetal toxins; those who can eat but are ill suffer from food accumulation. The changes from fetal toxins manifest as jaundice, tumors, and sores; the changes from food accumulation show as symptoms of pain and a feeling of fullness. Vomiting and diarrhea can be caused by cold or heat or food, while coughing may stem from deficiency, excess, or phlegm. Dysentery arises from accumulation, while malaria persists due to fullness.

    Bloating is due to deficiency of the spleen and stomach, while swelling results from wind and dampness. Hernias originate in the liver, while painful urination is due to heat in the bladder; jaundice arises from the spleen, and thirst is due to dryness of fluids.

    Wind arises from the liver, and heat dwells in the heart. When wind and heat combine, it causes severe spasms; prolonged vomiting and diarrhea result in a chronic state. Conditions can be classified into eight signs, and thorough treatment is critical. If phlegm has not been eliminated, there will be difficulty in speaking; if qi and blood have not been restored, there will be contractions of the limbs.

    There may be a hanging sensation that feels like a spasm and shoots upward; internal hanging sensations can feel like a hernia or cause internal pain. A slight disturbance may feel like inner malaise; pain from parasites resembles convulsions. When signs and symptoms are confused with one another, diagnosis and treatment should be detailed and careful.

    A white membrane in the eyes indicates a liver disorder; redness and ulcers below the nose signify a lung condition. Intense heat and thirst suggest evil fire attacking the palace of crimson; numerous sores and emaciation indicate the depletion of true fluids at the source. Injuries to diet lead to spleen damage; loss of fluids results in a dry stomach. The gradual thinning of limbs corresponds to the inability to nourish from spoiled grain.[61p]
    Loving to eat clay, with a yellow face, white teeth, and a shiny scalp; delighting in fruits, with a greedy mouth and a full, firm belly. The symptoms of illness are clear, and the treatment method is simple. To regulate the stomach and dry dampness, use Wuling and Pingwei, combining them to relieve both vomiting and diarrhea; for purging heat and dispelling wind, using the two formulas can also alleviate sudden convulsions. The coolness of golden flowers reduces fever, while the soothing jade liquid transforms phlegm. To harmonize the body and relieve accumulation, using Tongxiang can treat dysentery; while Yigong can nourish the spleen, assisting in the recovery from tuberculosis. To stop vomiting and diarrhea, with common strategies for both cold and heat, protecting life and calming sudden seizures, managing acute and chronic issues together. Embracing the dragon addresses sudden wind and resolves phlegm fire; clarity dispels transformations, dispersing wind and cold. Good for the spleen and treating malaria, especially for those with chronic complications; cardamom stops diarrhea, while those with long-term leaks balance the root. White Atractylodes cures thirst due to deficiency, while cloves are a miraculous remedy for parasitic accumulation. Five colors expel internal heat, three saints clear phlegm obstructing the diaphragm. For sores of the mouth and tongue, cleanse the heart; for acute pain in the chest and ribs, control the saliva. Ginseng and Poria nourish children; do not neglect those with severe spleen deficiency; Rehmannia supplements the kidneys, beneficial for those with weak constitution.

    Ah! Infants are fragile; how can they withstand harsh medications? Skilled practitioners of medicine especially value precision and specialization. Whether supplementing or purging, treatment should be immediately halted in case of wrong conditions; it’s easy to shift between deficiency and excess, so one must not offend the signs. If the treatment is not in accordance with the prescription, it is like trying to save someone drowning while also being burned; if the medicine does not match the illness, it is like wielding a sword unsafely. Reveal the secrets of my heart, seeking a rabbit to set a trap; gaining the benefits of this technique, do not forget the net when catching fish.[62p]
    Wealth and Poverty, Different Ailments

    There is a saying among people: the children of the rich who are often sick have clear vital energies and thin bodies, and they tend to be overindulged in warmth and food. In contrast, the children of the poor who are seldom sick have turbid vital energies and robust bodies, often enduring hunger and cold. A truly wise physician understands this principle, observing the parents to discern the thickness or thinness of their vital energies, and examining appearance to know the fullness or emptiness of the organs. Harsh or vigorous medicines should not be carelessly applied, nor should gentle remedies be used indiscriminately. The song says: "A physician who does not cling to conventions is a true master, capable of understanding the differences between wealth and poverty." From birth, vital energies are divided into clear and turbid; residing in different circumstances, they also change accordingly.[63p]
    Discussion on Diseases of Infancy: Foetal Disorders, Food Accumulation, and External Pathogens

    Infants often initially suffer from foetal disorders, and excessive eating leads to food accumulation. These two aspects serve as a framework for further discussion.

    Diseases in infants, such as smallpox, measles, umbilical wind, eruptions, jaundice, parasitic infections, convulsions, and conditions characterized by weakness, are all considered foetal disorders. In contrast, conditions like vomiting, diarrhea, malaria, swelling, food accumulation, and malnutrition are due to food injury. Only fever and cough, or cases involving external pathogens of wind and cold, are exceptions. Thus, it is said: among infants, 40% of illnesses are due to foetal toxins, 50% due to food injury, and 10-12% due to external pathogens.

    Seizures and convulsions arise from an excess in the liver, while the spleen is often insufficient, leading to malnutrition. A lack of development indicates a weakness in the kidneys, and skilled physicians should be mindful of these initial signs.

    Generally speaking, infants are characterized by an insufficient spleen and an excess in the liver. The kidneys are primarily weak and also insufficient. Therefore, in discussing infantile diseases, seizures are related to the liver, malnutrition to the spleen, and insufficient foetal energy to the kidneys. A skilled physician must first understand the underlying conditions to prevent illness, hence the saying: “Do not treat existing diseases; treat latent ones.”[64p]
    Three Traditional Methods of Treating Children

    The three family methods save children; for seizures, one must use the "Embrace the Dragon" technique. When the constitution is weak, it is appropriate to strengthen the kidneys, and for fat children with chronic diseases, there is remarkable efficacy.

    To treat seizures, use the "Amber Embrace the Dragon Pill," for dysentery use the "Fat Child Pill," and for insufficient prenatal constitution use the "Kidney-Replenishing Rehmannia Pill." These three formulas have been passed down through generations, respected and upheld by descendants.

If both parents are robust, the child’s form and energy are abundant; if both are weak, the child’s form and energy are deficient. If the father is strong and the mother weak, energy may be abundant while form is lacking; conversely, if the father is weak and the mother strong, form may be sufficient while energy is lacking.[65p]
    Generally, lifespan, fortune, intelligence, and foolishness are all predetermined; how can one escape this?     Differentiating Appearance and Color

    When a child is ill, observe their appearance and color: a blue hue indicates a shock from wind, red suggests heat, yellow implies food injury, and white indicates malnutrition. If affected by evil influences, the face will appear black. The liver governs wind, and its color is blue; the heart governs heat, and its color is red; the spleen governs grains, and its color is yellow. White represents a deficiency in qi and blood in the face, hence it suggests malnutrition. Black is an ominous color, indicating the influence of evil.

    The complexion should be observed according to different regions: the heart influences the forehead, producing a red fiery glow; the left cheek corresponds to wood (liver), while the right cheek relates to metal (lung); the chin signifies the kidneys and the nose relates to the spleen.

    These five forms correspond to their respective locations: the liver belongs to wood and the east, thus it is observed on the left cheek. The lung is associated with metal and the west, therefore it is checked on the right cheek. The heart pertains to fire and the south, hence it is examined on the forehead. The kidneys relate to water and the north, thus observed at the chin. The spleen corresponds to earth and the center, hence assessed at the nose.

    Liver illnesses should be observed in the eyes, while the spleen and heart connect through the lips and tongue. Lung issues often appear in the nose, and kidney problems are discerned from the ears.

    This relates the five openings to the five organs. Liver disease manifests in the eyes, heart disease appears on the tongue, spleen disease is visible on the lips, lung disease is apparent in the nose, and kidney disease can be seen in the ears, each determined by cold or heat, deficiency or excess.

    Differentiating Pulse and Breath

    For young children, their innate vital energy is still intact, so a pulse felt under the fingers should be strong. A large and slippery pulse that is numerous is most desirable, while a fine, thin, and slow pulse indicates deficiency, which is never auspicious. A large pulse indicates sufficient energy; a slippery pulse indicates strong blood. Six beats per breath signify a strong pulse, representative of an abundance. Conversely, a thin pulse signifies energy deficiency, and a weak pulse indicates blood deficiency. A pulse that reaches three beats on inhalation is considered slow and deficient, lacking strength; these are signs of insufficiency.

    In assessing children's lifespans, this method of differentiation is used. A pulse that is six beats per breath indicates harmony; the notion of eight beats should not be relied upon. Four beats or less signify a state of deficiency and cold, while eight, nine, or ten beats indicate heat, leading to agitation.

    A child's pulse typically corresponds to one breath with three beats on inhalation and three beats on exhalation, collectively termed "one breath." Six beats per breath represent a harmonious and healthy pulse. The rule states: do not rely on eight beats as a sign of balance. Four beats per breath are termed "leaving the canonical," while three beats or fewer denote "diminished pulse," associated with cold, imbalanced conditions. Conversely, eight beats per breath signify “leaving the canonical,” while nine beats and above indicate a "full pulse," linked to excess heat and convulsions.[71p]

    Differentiating Pulses and Treating Symptoms

    The foremost physician must understand both complexion and pulse thoroughly; the treatment of deficiency and excess must be applied according to the method. If there is one deviation, it will not be effective, leading to calamity for the child and transgressing heavenly laws. The "Inner Canon" states: being able to unify color and pulse ensures complete well-being. The highest physician treats children by correlating color with pulse and pulse with color; if it is excess, treat with purgatives; if it is deficiency, treat with tonics; if it does not deviate, then regulate it — this is the path to complete health.

    For instance, if the cheeks are red, it indicates excess color; if the pulse is rapid and forceful, it indicates excess pulse; constipation with yellow urine, unquenchable thirst, rapid breathing, and heat in the legs all signify an excess condition. When these three signs of excess are present, cold and cooling medicines should be used to purge. There are seven situations wherein warm medicine should not be administered.

    Conversely, if the face appears pale, it indicates deficient color; if the pulse is weak and deep, it indicates deficient pulse; bluish stools, abdominal distention, spitting up milk, blue scleras, and coldness in the legs indicate deficiency. When these three signs of deficiency are present, warm and nourishing medicines should be used to tonify. There are seven situations wherein cold medicine should not be administered.

    Currently, inexperienced practitioners know nothing of color, pulse, and symptom treatment, carelessly concocting decoctions and pills, endangering children's lives, and the heavens will surely punish such actions. Medicines must correspond accurately to the symptoms without error, and the condition must not exceed moderation. Wait until the true qi returns fully and nourishment is sufficient to support recovery.

    This is what is meant by the essential techniques in treating illnesses.[72p]
    In treating conditions based on color and pulse, one must understand these principles in the heart: thus, cold conditions are treated with heat, and hot conditions with cold. In reality, for excess conditions, one drains, and for deficiency conditions, one supplements; all are methods and remedies to control disease. After taking medicine, if the illness has already diminished, one should not exceed the prescribed dosage. This aligns with the teachings from the "Inner Canon" which states that for severe toxicity, one should reduce the treatment by a third; for moderate toxicity, reduce by half; and for non-toxic conditions, reduce by seven tenths. The "Inner Canon" also states that when a condition is waning, one should wait for its recovery, meaning when the illness has diminished by half, one should stop the medication to allow the true vital energy to recover, supplemented by nourishing food to aid this recovery. It is said in a proverb that food supplements are preferable to medicinal supplements—a truth that coarse practitioners fail to understand. They attack cold with heat, causing internal heat to arise before the cold has dissipated; they counter heat with cold, allowing cold to set in before the heat has subsided. How can one expect recovery? The basis of premature death certainly starts here. These treatment principles are what I strictly adhere to in practice.

    When prescribing for children, one must choose only the finest remedies, for even the slightest toxic substance is unacceptable. If pathogenic energy has not been eliminated and vital energy is depleted, it is pitiful how fragile young sprouts cannot withstand frost.

    The "fine" refers to medicines that are mild, balanced, and non-toxic, while "toxic" refers to harsh and caustic medicines that may cause dizziness or impairment. Therefore, remedies for children should actually drain excess, such as those that clear the green bile, guide out the red bile, drain the white bile, or eliminate the yellow bile; if deficient, one should supplement, such as tranquilizing with substances like antler gelatin or rehmannia. Remedies that cool heat, regulate cold, treat convulsions, or nourish children to combat malnutrition are all gentle and non-toxic, and these are my family's secret formulas. While substances like croton and morning glory are not never used, I am cautious and do not resort to them as primary remedies.[73p]
    I see that those who practice pediatrics today use various toxic medicines: sulfur to treat phlegm, arsenic for malaria, and other powerful substances. These are highly toxic drugs, and children's digestive systems are delicate; how can they withstand such poisons?

    When treating children, do not lightly induce sweating, as genuine conditions will be harmed. Mistaking the treatment for cold and heat can lead to excessive harm, while warming the middle and detoxifying can provide miraculous effects.

    According to Zhang Zhongjing's principles for treating cold damage: when one should not sweat but is made to sweat, it signifies a condition of rash with excessive sweating; this can lead to severe outcomes. When one should not be purged but is, this indicates ailments of abdominal fullness, pain, vomiting, and uncontrollable diarrhea; excessive purging can lead to dire consequences.

    When a child is ill, do not purge unless there is fever, sweating, or spontaneous diarrhea. Signs of distress include cold limbs, weak spirit, dry retching, and fear.

    Symptoms like vomiting roundworms, pale face, hair loss, failure to digest food, nasal congestion, coughing, and thin phlegm indicate a troubled pulse and anxiety. If there is accumulation of waste, it is genuinely alarming.

    If a child shows true heat, purging does no harm; they may have a flushed face, red eyes, and strong energy. The pulse feels tense, and the abdomen is hot; there may be throat pain and urine resembling broth. Hard stools, abdominal bloating, fullness in the sides, and swollen limbs, coupled with nighttime crying, may signify severe underlying issues that require treatment.

    If a child suffers from the excessive use of cooling medicines, it can lead to weakened spleen and stomach and pain in the stomach area; warming the stomach is appropriate here. Conversely, if heat medicines have been overused, causing agitation, restlessness, vomiting, madness, or thirst, detoxification is needed first, and a drink of mung bean powder should be given.[74p]
    When a child suffers from fright, it is common to treat them with excessively warm or heating medications. There are instances where, even before the fright resolves, another heat condition emerges; others may have recovered from the illness yet develop heat symptoms, or the condition may worsen into a severe fright. When asking the patient over the days about how the condition arose and which medicines were used, detoxifying medications can be applied with effectiveness. The bean roll powder can be used for this.

    When fever arises, if the patient is not alert, they may trust ghosts or divine spirits rather than the physician. It is unheard of that rituals by dragon wood or shamanic practices can resolve someone’s fright through animal sacrifice.

    The classics say: those who are confused by ghosts and spirits are not worth discussing profound virtues with. Hence, there is a caution against believing in shamans while ignoring doctors. The traditions conveyed through shamanic practices are merely techniques of transforming essence and altering qi. Prayer to spirits often involves animal sacrifice, but of what benefit is that?

    One should not speak openly of their illness; treatment requires focused intention. From the beginning, the three methods should be memorized, and care should be taken not to harm the spleen and stomach, which could lead to complications.

    An ancient saying goes: If an illness cannot be treated, one should reveal it early, and not endure it in silence to avoid being ridiculed. This statement holds true. If the illness can be treated, one should care for the child as they would for their own. Nurturing and providing care must be thorough. There are three approaches: first, use vigorous methods to drive away the illness; one should not excessively attack while favoring supplements, as this will only aid the evil and harm the child. Second, apply a combination of vigorous and gentle methods; if the illness lingers, food intake must be limited, and the spleen and stomach weakened, so in spleen supplements, add medicinal ingredients to address the illness, adjusting according to the child’s strength. Lastly, gentle methods should be employed; if the child has been ill for a long time, it could lead to malnutrition, focusing primarily on nourishing the spleen and stomach will ensure that the right qi is strengthened, which will cause the evil qi to dissipate naturally.[75p]

    Pulse Diagnosis[76p]
    From the age of one to three, one should observe the pulse at the tigertail position, applying the finger to press the higher segments. Thus, one finger divides into three sections to determine the pulse rate. A breath count of eight indicates a normal pulse, nine indicates unease, and ten indicates a dangerous condition. Each pulse's length and size reflects various ailments. A floating pulse indicates wind, a rapid pulse suggests fright, a slow and deep pulse signifies deficiency and coldness, a strong pulse indicates heat, a tight pulse suggests convulsions, a full pulse indicates excessive heat, a deep and thin pulse suggests abdominal pain, a slow and deep pulse indicates deficiency and diarrhea, a faint and slow pulse suggests accumulation or worms, a slow and thick pulse indicates disharmony in the stomach, a deep pulse suggests difficulty in digesting milk, a deep and thin pulse suggests milk accumulation, a tight and wiry pulse indicates abdominal heat and pain, a firm pulse indicates constipation, and a deep but rapid pulse suggests internal heat in the bones. A long and wiry pulse suggests wind in the liver and diaphragm, a tight and rapid pulse indicates convulsions and spasms, a floating and full pulse indicates heat in the stomach, a deep and tight pulse suggests persistent abdominal pain, a weak and soft pulse implies a mix of energy deficiency and slow fright, and a wide pulse with frequent diarrhea indicates blood in the stool.

    At four years old, one should use one finger to press on the fullness and emptiness; at five and six, one should roll the finger to explore the three positions, with a normalized pulse at the central spot. At seven and eight, one should slightly adjust the finger to explore the three positions. At nine and ten, one should sequentially examine the locations corresponding to the three sections. At eleven and twelve, one examines similarly to the ten-year-olds. At fourteen and fifteen, one should examine according to the larger pulse positions.

    In all pulse examinations, one must first determine floating or deep, slow or rapid, and the balance of yin and yang, hot and cold, all in relation to the larger pulse. A deep and slow pulse represents yin, while a floating and rapid pulse represents yang. It is also essential to examine facial color: a bluish tone indicates fright, a pale tone indicates deficiency and diarrhea, a reddish tone indicates phlegm-heat, a blackish tone suggests a grave condition, and a yellow tone indicates spleen-related accumulation. Utilizing this method to analyze the symptoms will yield accurate assessments for treatment, ensuring nothing is overlooked.[77p]
    On the face, the evidence of one's health can be seen.

    The left cheek corresponds to the liver, the right cheek to the lungs, the forehead to the heart, the nose to the spleen, and the chin to the kidneys. Blue signifies discharge followed by agitation, and excessive black and yellow indicate death. If one’s lifespan is level and falls, it indicates premature death. Blue signifies fever and shock; black indicates dysentery leading to death, while red indicates death from dryness. A slight yellow indicates balance; excessive yellow signifies death from cholera. Blue due to shock from wind results in death; black gas around the mouth suggests death. Both eyes have black and yellow indicating heat; white sclera signifies undigested food causing sores or roundworms; white with blue indicates liver wind and shock, while black sclera with yellow indicates typhoid.     General Discussion on Pediatric Pulse Diagnosis

    Children aged seven to eight are referred to as "Chun," and those aged nine to ten as "Tiao." At this stage, one can begin to feel the pulse at the three pulse positions behind the wrist using a single finger, with a normal pulse characterized by seven to eight beats per breath. From eleven to fourteen years old, they are called "Tongcao," and a normal pulse is defined by five to six beats per breath.

    A rapid pulse indicates heat, while a slower pulse suggests cold; a floating pulse indicates deficiency or wind, and a deep pulse points to fullness or pain. A floating and rapid pulse could signify乳癎 (a kind of childhood convulsion) or anxiety, a weak and soft pulse indicates chronic anxiety or seizures, a tight and solid pulse suggests wind convulsions, a firm and leathery pulse is connected to constipation, a deep and string-like pulse indicates food stagnation or abdominal pain, a tense and string-like pulse indicates respiratory distress due to wind-cold, and a strong and rapid pulse points to heat, while a hidden pulse implies food damage. A pulse that is chaotic, uneven, or alternates with shortness of breath signals imminent death if not treated promptly.[80p]
    Song of Manifest Symptoms

    Dysentery furrows the brow, shock reddens the cheeks. Thirst brings red lips, poison and heat cloud the eyes.

    The continuous red must not be treated lightly, as it surely means the nurse’s milk is unsuited. If both hands suddenly show no pulse, it is certain that maliciousness has offended the divine.[82p]
    Internal Eight Segment Brocade

    Clearing the blood brings peace, no need for alarm; when encountering red and black, chaos ensues. Even more so, in confusion between red and green, one must dispel phlegm and disease to regain health.
    A slight red signals external disturbance; like a grain of rice, the force may be difficult to handle. Red dispersions often arise from anger, and sudden convulsions become hard to settle.
    When a newborn suffers abdominal pain, their brows furrow; this is called intestinal gas, leading to wailing and groaning.
    If they appear to look upwards as if in disbelief, it is due to a wind disturbance.
    In the first month after birth, the infant appears emaciated, with scant hair and sparse down; it is originally due to the spirit of the king in the womb.

    External Eight Segment Brocade

    First, observe the child's eye color; next, check if the back feels cold as ice. For a male child, convulsions on the left are not a concern, but those on the right are quite alarming. For a female child, convulsions on the right can still be treated; however, if they convulse on the left, the condition is serious.
    A crooked mouth and eyes will ultimately cause harm; even with elixirs, there is no remedy.[83p]
    Preserving Infants’ Golden Mirror Records
    [Ming Dynasty, Xue Ji]

    Diagram of the Head and Face Regions

    The head is where various Yang meridians converge; the face reflects the nourishment of the five organs' qi and blood. Color represents the spirit of the five organs. To discern a child's illness or well-being, one must first distinguish the positions of growth and decline. When the five organs are weak, the complexion will certainly appear shriveled; when the five colors are full, the complexion will be bright. A vibrant complexion indicates life, while a withered complexion indicates death. Since observation precedes diagnosis, it is said: the ability to observe color and pulse can lead to comprehensive well-being. According to "Complete Reflection on Childhood," if a child is ill within six months, one should press three fingers horizontally on the forehead, between the eyebrows and hairline.

    When the child's head is raised on the left, use the right hand; when raised on the right, use the left hand. The index finger represents the upper area, the middle finger the middle area, and the ring finger the lower area. If all three fingers are hot, it indicates the invasion of wind pathogenic factors, with symptoms like nasal congestion, rough breathing, fever, and cough. If all three fingers are cold, it suggests external invasion and internal damage, with symptoms like fever, vomiting, and diarrhea. If the index and middle fingers are hot, it indicates heat above and cold below; if the middle finger is hot, it suggests a shock; if only the index finger is hot, it indicates fullness in the chest; if only the ring finger is hot, it suggests undigested milk or food.

    I privately assert that a red forehead indicates heart wind heat, leading to agitation and uneasiness. If there is fever and thirst for water, or if the child cries incessantly, it pertains to real heat in the heart meridian, and one should use a cooling heart decoction to clear heart fire.[84p]

This is due to虚热, and one should use the secret method Anshen Pill to nourish the heart's blood. Slightly yellow and dry skin indicates a shocking type of dysentery, relating to heart dysentery; the secret method Anshen Pill is used to nourish the heart's blood. Bone steaming with thirst and night sweats, along with hair turning dry and yellow, indicates kidney dysentery; use Dihuang Pill to nourish the liver and kidneys.

A slightly red color and teeth grinding indicate虚热, and one should use Dihuang Pill to supplement it. Dark blue suggests liver overcoming spleen, with cold shock, convulsions, and abdominal pain; one should use the Six Gentlemen Decoction, ginger, and cinnamon to warm it. A slight red indicates tidal fever with heart blood deficiency and restlessness; use the secret method Anshen Pill in conjunction with Dihuang Pill.

If there is a sensation of choking with shortness of breath and pale lips, this indicates虚热; use Wuwai Yigong Powder. If it is transmitted by spleen heat, use Qingwei Powder. Use the Liu Junzi Decoction with added Diaoteng to tonify the original qi; do not treat the liver directly.

A pale white indicates weak spleen qi, leading to diarrhea and difficulty in digesting food; use Liu Junzi for tonification. A blue coloration signifies cold in the spleen earth, with the liver wood dominating; use the Wuwi Yigong Powder, adding musk and toasted ginger to warm the middle and balance the liver. Black signifies a terminal condition.[86p]

If the nostrils are slightly yellow and the right cheek is slightly red, this indicates spleen and lung dryness-heat, unable to transform and generate kidney water; use Huang Qin Qing Fei Decoction. If bladder yin is deficient, and yang is unable to be generated, use Zi Shen Wan. If there is slight redness in the area between the chin, it indicates bladder yang deficiency, where yin is unable to transform; use Ba Wei Di Huang Wan. If accompanied by fullness in the lower abdomen or swelling of the scrotum, this belongs to yin deficiency with damp-heat stagnation; use Liu Wei Wan added with Plantago Seed and Achyranthes. If there is also spleen and lung qi deficiency preventing proper regulation of water pathways, use the same previous formula. If the urine is red, persisting and leading to blood in the urine, this indicates liver and kidney qi deficiency with heat; use Liu Wei Di Huang Wan for treatment. Urgently use Liu Junzi Decoction to tonify the middle qi, and all ailments will self-resolve; avoid cool medicines. If the lips are red, dry, and wrinkled, it indicates heat in the spleen meridian, causing fever and thirst, foul breath, constipation, and irritability leading to insomnia. First treat the heat with Qingwei Powder, and further use Liu Junzi Decoction with Huang Lian and Shan Zhi to supplement the spleen.

    A yellow color indicates food stagnation and diarrhea in the spleen meridian, where food doesn’t digest; use Liu Junzi Decoction to warm and tonify the middle qi. If there is drooling and the lips are purple, it indicates weak cold stomach qi; use Yi Huang San.[89p]
    If there is pain in the abdomen accompanied by spitting saliva, it is due to worms. First, use Wuyi Powder, then follow with Tiaozhong Pill. If there is no salivation, the pain is due to accumulation; simply use Wuwai Yigong Powder to nourish the stomach qi. If the hands and feet are cold, use Lichong Decoction with dried plum to warm and nourish the middle qi, so that the worms will not move and the pain will stop. There are also cases of accumulation pain where vomiting or bowel movement can relieve the pain; for these, use Xiaojiyuan Pill to eliminate and guide away the stagnant accumulation, supplemented with Yigong Powder to nourish the stomach qi. White indicates loss of blood, leading to death. Blue indicates wind stroke, leading to death. Black around the mouth indicates no treatment can be effective.

    A slight redness in front of the ear indicates wind-heat in the Shaoyang channel; use Chaihu and Zhizi Powder to nourish liver blood and clear liver fire. A mild yellow indicates night terrors during sleep and teeth grinding due to the deficiency of liver and spleen heat; the use of the Four Gentlemen Decoction with Chuanxiong, Angelica, and Schizonepeta is recommended to calm the spirit.

    If the ear lobes are dry, it indicates steaming heat from bone sores, which is due to deficiency heat in the kidney channel; use Liuwuwei Dihuang Pill to replenish this. If there is discharge of white fluid after urination or itching and pain of the penis, it indicates liver channel damp-heat; first use Longdan Cao Decoction, then follow with Liuwuwei Dihuang Pill. If there is insufficient kidney qi from constitution or early exposure to women causing urinary stagnation or pain like dysuria, urgently use Liuwuwei Dihuang Pill and Buzhong Yiqi Decoction to nourish the source of transformation.[90p]
    If there is pain associated with urination or defecation, it is particularly a sign of deficiency. One should use the previously mentioned medicine, adding Achyranthes bidentata, Plantago seeds, and cinnamon to alleviate it. If hands and feet are cold and there is fear of cold and reduced appetite, it indicates a deficiency of Yang energy and coldness; therefore, one should urgently add a larger dosage of Aconite root if there is vitality. Generally, in children's cases, many arise from inherent imbalances in the organs, improper food and season, or from the six excesses and seven emotions impacting pregnant women and nursing mothers.

    If initially, the vital energy is not depleted, and food intake is normal, yet there is high fever, constipation, thirst for water, and sleeping with eyes open, this indicates substantial illness and requires treatment for the pathogenic qi. If the condition has persisted, with diminished vital energy, reduced food intake, fever, dry mouth, vomiting, diarrhea, cold intolerance in limbs, and sleeping with eyes open, this indicates a substantial illness due to deficiency, and one should tonify the vital qi.

    Moreover, the vital energy in today's children differs from that of the past; inappropriate medication can harm the spleen and stomach, so one cannot simply adhere to ancient prescriptions in treatment. Therefore, I have referred to renowned experts and followed the teachings of the Eastern Garden, supplementing with appropriate prescriptions for various symptoms. A practitioner ought to observe the patient’s complexion to assess their condition, examine the illness to strengthen the root, and this will yield no mistakes. Thus, in ancient medicine, checking the complexion was paramount. Furthermore, when startled, the qi disperses and the pulse becomes disordered, so one cannot focus solely on diagnosis and must also examine the complexion. The "Heart Mirror" states: if the facial color is incomplete, one should also consult the pulse; if the pulse is incomplete, one should look at the facial color; when both color and pulse are fully evaluated, there remains no hidden condition.[91p]
    Summary of Infant Protection
    [Ming - Xue Kai]

    Facial Diagnosis

    A blue complexion indicates lingering fright that has not dispersed, signaling a potential wind condition. Red denotes phlegm accumulation and anxiety. Yellow suggests food stagnation affecting the body, indicating the onset of intestinal ailments. A pale complexion points to diarrhea from food and drink, possibly leading to vomiting. Black signifies a critical condition of the internal organs. A blue area on the glabella (the space between the eyebrows) denotes initial fright-induced diarrhea; red indicates severe fright with night crying, while black suggests an obstructive issue. Blue at the root of the nose signifies a second bout of fright; increased agitation after diarrhea indicates serious condition; significant black and yellow may lead to death. A flat lifespan line suggests potential early death; blue signifies heat-induced fright, black indicates a fatal outcome, red suggests restlessness leading to death, subtle yellow indicates stability, while prominent yellow signifies cholera.

    A blue tint at the承浆 (the area below the lower lip) signifies fright during feeding; yellow indicates vomiting and also points to blood in stools; black indicates wind-induced fright. Yellow in the whites of the eyes signifies heat; yellow in the blue of the eyes denotes food stagnation and intestinal worms; blue in the whites indicates fright-induced convulsions; yellow in the blue of the eyes signifies typhus.

    A blue mark above the eyebrows is auspicious; sudden red indicates restlessness and night crying, while yellow may suggest cholera, and prolonged redness may be fatal.

    Wind conditions may appear in the two pools (areas near the eyes); blue indicates a wind condition, purple may signal vomiting or fever, yellow indicates vomiting, and red indicates restlessness and night crying.

    Red cheeks denote possible lung heat. Blue at the temples suggests a second incidence of fright; if the blue spreads from the temples to the ears, it may result in death; red indicates blood in urine.

    Blue on both sides of the face points to an obstructive issue, yellow denotes phlegm overflow, and red signifies wind heat.

    Both red cheeks suggest typhus, while blue at the mandibles indicates potential worm infestation.[92p]
    The two golden urns indicate that when the blue leader suffers from a sudden wind three times, the black leader (causing) throat issues will lead to death in two days, while the blue (one) entering the ears will die in seven days. The two wind doors indicate that the red leader, who suffers from wind-heat, the black (one) leads to hernia, the blue (one) indicates water shock, and the black enters the ears from the eyebrows, causing death on the same day. Those with black lips and cannot eat will die.

    Pulse Forms

    The "flowing pearl" shape indicates injury from food, internal heat wanting to vomit, or gurgling intestines with diarrhea, irritability, and crying. Use gastric paste to mitigate food effects, separating yin and yang; if digestion occurs but illness persists, use fragrant sand to help gastric paste to tonify the spleen and stomach. The "ringed pearl" shape indicates spleen deficiency with food stagnation, fullness and congestion in the chest, and thirst with fever. Use the modified Five Flavors Essence Powder with mountain pear and bitter orange to strengthen the spleen and aid digestion, followed by Six Gentlemen Decoction to nourish the central qi. The "long pearl" shape indicates spleen injury, food accumulation, abdominal pain, intolerance of cold and heat, and inability to eat. First, use Great Tranquility Pills to resolve accumulation, followed by Essence Powder to strengthen spleen qi. The "coming snake" shape indicates damp-heat in the spleen and stomach, blockage in the middle section, dry retching, and inability to eat. This is an internal evil of malnutrition; first, use the Four Flavor Fat Child Pills to treat malnutrition, followed by Four Gentlemen Decoction to tonify the spleen. The "going snake" shape indicates spleen deficiency with food accumulation, vomiting, diarrhea, thirst, shortness of breath, anxiety, inability to eat, and fatigue. First, use Six Gentlemen Decoction with bitter orange to strengthen the spleen and resolve accumulation, followed by Seven Flavor Atractylodes Powder to nourish the stomach qi.[93p]
    The bow-shaped condition indicates a cold invasion causing symptoms such as chills, difficulty breathing, anxiety, fatigue, cold extremities, red urine, cough with phlegm. First, use the Xingxing Powder to enhance stomach qi and expel external pathogens, then add Wuwei Yigong Powder with Poria and Angelica to nourish heart blood and support stomach qi. If the external pathogen is resolved but anxiety and cold fingers persist, it indicates spleen qi injury; in this case, use Qiwwei Baizhu Powder for supplementation. If there are severe issues like breathlessness and difficulty breathing, it may be difficult to treat due to significant spleen deficiency.

    The outward bow shape suggests phlegm-heat causing confusion of the mind, with mix-ups from fright and food. For excessive phlegm from wind and spasms, start with Tianma Fangfeng Pills to eliminate external pathogens, and then use Wuwei Yigong Powder to regulate middle qi.

    The spear shape indicates wind-heat generating phlegm and convulsions. Start with Baolong Pills; if ineffective, use Niu Huang Qingxin Pills. If it progresses to the spleen and lungs or if wind-phlegm medications are misused, focus on supplementing the spleen and stomach.

    The fish bone shape signifies driving phlegm and generating heat; begin with Baolong Pills for treatment. If ineffective, it relates to excessive liver fire, thus use a small amount of Yizhi Qing Pills to clear the liver, while continuing with Liuwei Pills to nourish the liver.[94p]
    When there is a fever and loss of appetite, or excessive phlegm causing convulsions, this indicates that the wood of the liver overcomes the earth of the spleen. Use the Six Gentlemen Decoction combined with Radix Bupleuri to tonify the spleen's earth and restrain the liver's wood.

    The water shape corresponds to wind fright and food accumulation, with chest oppression, irritability, and reduced appetite, or nighttime crying with excessive phlegm, and closed mouth with convulsions. This reflects weakness of the spleen and stomach, with food stagnation and the wood overcoming the earth. First, use the Great Tranquility Pill to transform and guide food, followed by the Six Gentlemen Decoction and vine hook to strengthen the middle and clear the liver. If these are taken and the condition does not improve, then combine Four Gentlemen, Radix Cimicifugae, Bupleurum, and vine hook to bolster spleen qi and pacify the liver wood.

    For the needle shape, this addresses extreme heart and liver heat generating wind, with palpitations and irritability, drowsiness and loss of appetite, and phlegm causing convulsions. Start with the Bao Long Pill to expel wind and transform phlegm, and then use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with vine hook to calm the liver and strengthen the spleen.

    The piercing finger shape indicates wind fright with phlegm-heat gathering in the chest and diaphragm, which arises from damage to the spleen and lungs, allowing phlegm evil to accumulate. Begin with the Niu Huang Qing Xin Pill to clear the spleen and lungs and transform phlegm; then follow with the Six Gentlemen Decoction, adding Platycodon and Dioscorea to tonify the spleen's earth and nourish the lung's metal.[95p]
    Through the analysis of the condition, the primary concern is the wind attacking the liver, which can overpower the spleen's earth. In urgent cases, use Six Gentlemen, Mu Xiang, Diaoteng Gou, and Guang Gui to warm and tonify the spleen. If there is no response, add Fu Zi to revive the Yang Qi, which often helps those who are seriously ill.

    I've heard ancient people say: children are like young sprouts, soft like grass shoots or water's soak. This is because their organs are fragile, and they cannot express themselves, making medication difficult to administer. One should first observe the complexion to understand the condition, and then check the tiger's mouth to discern its cause—this is a concise approach to treatment.

    Note: The flowing beads show just a point of red; the ring beads differ in size, and the long beads are oval and elongated. The above does not refer to loops, but rather to the red veins penetrating the Qi. Coming snake is like long bead scatter, with one end thick and the other sharp. The departing snake is the same. The distinction of upper and lower aspects leads to their naming. The horn bow bent outward shows repression, while inward indicates smoothness. The spear shape points straight up, the fishbone diverges, and the water character symbolizes the simultaneous flow of three pulses. The needle shape indicates a pass with a few grains of rice, with the penetrating meridian directed outward while the life meridian curves in. However, I have also treated conditions without exclusively focusing on their shapes and pulses—there are cases where specific treatments with particular medications have yielded good results.[96p]
    Ancient and Modern Medical Guide (Ming Dynasty, Gong Xin)

    Singing of Illness Indicated by the Color of Children's Three Passages

    Purple indicates heat and red signifies cold damage; blue signals fright and white suggests malnutrition. Black appears due to internal evils, while yellow indicates obstruction in the spleen.
    Blue color indicates growth abnormalities with fright affecting all four limbs; red color signifies growth anomalies influenced by water, fire, and birds.
    Purple color indicates harm to grains, flour, fish, and meat. Black color suggests slight wind from the spleen causing convulsions.
    Song of Variations in the Three Passages' Pulse Patterns[97p]
    The presence of fishbone causing wind syndrome should not be doubted; it is accompanied by qi-related illness and heat. When the life gate shows this, it is difficult to treat, as it indicates a transition from the liver to the spleen.

    Initially, the suspended needle can lead to dysentery; the qi gate shows lung heat further aggravating the illness. When the three gates are directly linked to the underworld, it is important to recognize this as a chronic fright.

    Water-related fright indicates the lungs have received wind; the qi gate experiences wheezing and cough with accumulated phlegm. Physicians should carefully analyze the deficiencies and excesses; the onset of fright viewed alongside this illness is ominous.

    The character '乙' represents fright affecting the liver and lungs; the qi gate manifests with sudden emergencies. If this form appears directly at the life gate, it won't take long to develop into a chronic spleen issue.

    The curled worm indicates the onset of illness; if the qi gate shows stagnant toxins in the liver. Once it reaches the life gate, it is untreatable, and one must know that the heart has transmitted to the liver.

    When double rings indicate deep liver illness, vomiting and nausea arise from the gastric qi gate. If the life gate shows signs of imminent death, it’s futile for physicians to exhaust their efforts.

    When flowing pearls are seen, death approaches; even if the face looks like this, the person will not survive. Though there may be miraculous pills, no one can save them. Physicians must still be meticulous and attentive.

    In cases of typhoid, the inclination is to the right; for food injury, seven should be cautious. If there's cold injury, it is determined; when startled, mountain-shaped signs appear. If the thread-like pattern emerges, the abundant shape leads to worry. If one encounters wind syndrome, the pulse tilts to the left.

    The form resembles a crescent moon, feeling left within qi and heat distress. If it bends to the left, wind and heat medicines can be used. Forms like three folds indicate an enmity with solid objects. Additional rings forming the legs especially distrust the upper and lower hooks.

    All these are signs of cold injuries; physicians should diligently seek to understand. A severe illness resembles exhaustion; all kinds of worms can be a concern. With entangled and overlapping lines, conditions on the abdomen reveal the source.

    Moreover, visible blue veins cutting through indicate there is an extremely low chance of recovery.[98p]
    Pulse Diagnosis Verse

    When a child is ill, rely on the pulse; one finger on three positions determines the breath. Slow and cold, or fast and hot, passed down through the ages. Floating, windy, sinking, and stagnant, recognize these first. The left hand at the "Renying" indicates external symptoms, while the right at "Qikou" points to internal diseases. Observe for invasion of wind, cold, heat, and dampness from the outside; from the inside, consider milk, food, phlegm, and accumulation. A large and tight pulse indicates harm from cold; a floating and soft pulse with sweat suggests a cold wind. A floating and full pulse often indicates excess of wind-heat, while a sinking and thin pulse is due to accumulation of milk and food. A tight and sinking pulse with persistent abdominal pain; a wiry and tight pulse indicates breathlessness in the throat. A tight pulse can give rise to rashes and boils, while a rapid pulse may lead to convulsions. A soft and thin pulse suggests parasites, while a firm and solid pulse indicates constipation. A flooding pulse shows blood in the stool, and a weak, moist pulse accompanies anxiety. A slippery pulse indicates injury from exposure to dampness and cold. A tense and rapid pulse must be noted for its adverse effects. Discrepancies in size indicate critical conditions; two beats indicate collapse, three indicate sudden fatality. Five signifies deficiency, four indicates harm, while six, balanced and harmonious, implies no illness. Seven and eight reflect milder conditions, nine and ten indicate severity. Eleven and twelve pulses confirm inevitable death; this principle is rarely wrong.[99p]
    Pulse Diagnosis Song

    Children's index fingers differentiate three positions, with boys on the left and girls on the right. All know the initial wind and climate; the end is the fate gate, easy yet difficult. To understand the pulse patterns at the tiger's mouth, observe the lines from an inverted position, divided into five colors. Yellow and red signify harmony of the five organs; red and purple indicate gains and losses. Purple and blue suggest damage from excessive eating and weariness, while black patterns point to reverse conditions. Suddenly, pure black appears amidst, making skilled doctors' hearts tremble. If it rises straight to the wind gate, the lengths of rice grains split at both ends. Like a gunshot startled by the wind, the fingers form various splits. A reversed bow indicates outward conditions, while intermingling of forward and reverse signifies difficult illnesses. The length of the splits can be treated; thus, doctors must observe carefully. A boy of two years is still considered an infant, while two to four years old is the young one's name. By five or six, youth grows gradually; at seven and eight, feelings begin to be discerned.[100p]
    When a child is nine-tenths in age and exhibits illness, one must discern the cause of the condition. At eleven, epilepsy is known as "falling wind," while malnutrition resembles the afflictions of fatigue. A heaviness or stagnation is often identified, with a distinct feeling of heat or variations in temperature. Initially, a warm palm indicates the body's heat condition. If the belly feels warm while the body is cold, this suggests an accumulation of issues. Warm feet and a hot forehead imply a wind invasion, while a cool forehead and warm feet indicate fright. Rash and sores may erupt with redness behind the ears. For children with accumulated issues, emesis is advisable, especially in cases of three types of febrile illness. During food-related diarrhea, it is essential to manage accumulations, and for cold diarrhea, warming the spleen is necessary. For watery diarrhea, focus on draining excess from the organs. If a child suddenly cries out without reason, it may not be due to wind but rather a celestial disturbance. A loud cry with rapid breathing and a rough voice may indicate the ingestion of hot toxic substances causing distress. Immediate vomiting and harmonizing the spleen is crucial; administering fright-relieving medicines could be humorous under the circumstances.[101p]
    Theory of Pathogens

    Children are in the early stage of life. The newborn is called an infant, a three-year-old is called a child, and a ten-year-old is called a youth. There are different sizes among children, and the severity of diseases varies among them. By observing their shape, color, voice, and pulse, if one can investigate these details carefully, they could be regarded as a skilled and wise practitioner.

    To observe is to discern appearance and color. For example, the left cheek corresponds to the liver, the right cheek to the lungs, the forehead to the heart, the nose to the spleen, and the chin to the kidneys. If there is liver disease, the face turns green; if lung disease, the face turns pale; if heart disease, the face turns red; if spleen disease, the face turns yellow; and if kidney disease, the face turns dark. This is knowledge derived from observation.

    To hear is to understand the condition through sound. For instance, with liver disease, the voice is mournful; with lung disease, the voice is hurried; with heart disease, the voice is strong; with spleen disease, the voice is slow; and with kidney disease, the voice is deep. These pertain to the organs. Additionally, if there is disease in the large intestine, the voice is prolonged; in the small intestine, the voice is short; in the stomach, the voice is quick; in the gallbladder, the voice is clear; and in the bladder, the voice is faint. This is knowledge derived from hearing.

    To inquire is to ask about the disease’s origins. For example, if a person craves sour food, they may have liver disease; if they crave spicy food, they may have lung disease; if they crave bitter food, they may have heart disease; if they crave sweet food, they may have spleen disease; if they crave salty food, they may have kidney disease; if they prefer hot food, they may have internal cold; and if they prefer cold food, they may have internal heat. This is knowledge derived from inquiry.

    To palpate is to feel the pulse and detect the disease.[102p]
    If a three-year-old child is unwell, first examine the left hand for boys and the right hand for girls at the tiger mouth's three points. From the side of the second finger, the first joint is called "Wind Point," the second joint is called "Qi Point," and the third joint is called "Life Point." By distinguishing their colors and patterns: purple indicates heat, red signifies injury from cold, blue represents wind disturbance, white points to malnutrition, black denotes poison, and yellow reflects spleen distress. If observed at the Wind Point, the condition is mild; if at the Qi Point, it is severe; if exceeding the Life Point, it is difficult to treat.

    For children over three years old, use one finger to press the inch, guan, and chi parts. Typically, six to seven beats are the standard; an increase suggests heat, a decrease implies cold, a floating pulse indicates excessive wind, a rapid pulse indicates frequent surprises, a deep and slow pulse implies deficiency, while a deep and firm pulse indicates accumulation. This is how one discerns through pulse diagnosis.

    Generally, most illnesses in children arise from intrauterine toxins, with few resulting from dietary harm. External symptoms of wind and cold are usually limited. When a child is still in the womb, if the mother is hungry, the child feels it; if the mother is full, the child feels it too. Spicy or strong flavors can increase the fetal energy; emotional disturbances of the mother can agitate the child. Overeating fried or harsh foods, indulgence in overly spicy or acidic tastes, emotional volatility, or uncontrolled desires can all lead to problems for the child.

    As for the mother, if she cannot exercise caution during pregnancy and fails to care properly after childbirth, she may only seek quick relief, neglecting prevention. This may lead to introducing overly salty or sour tastes before the child is even a hundred days old, or sweet and fatty foods before the child is one year old, resulting in various diseases. A child's spleen and stomach are inherently delicate and easily harmed by accumulation.[103p]
    If milk and food harm the stomach, it will lead to vomiting; if they harm the spleen, it will cause diarrhea. Prolonged vomiting and diarrhea can result in chronic fright or may lead to malnutrition.
